/trv/ is a slow board, so don't expect immediate responses. CHECK THE CATALOG – you might find threads already discussing topics you're interested in.

Before asking for suggestions, tell /trv/ about your:
>Budget
>Interests
>Level of understanding of the local language(s)
This makes it easier to give quality advice. Of course, keep your posts travel related.

For all other matters:
General culture questions >>>/int/
Politics discussion >>>/pol/
Transportation discussion >>>/n/
Outdoors-related discussion >>>/out/

Just got back from Siquijor.
It's a paradise. Mystic, enchanted vibes with all the huge trees and dense forest growing around. Well preserved marine sanctuaries with lots of cool fish, including sharks and barracuda schools. It's abundant with blue-greenish waterfalls and rivers, it's also very cheap, roads are very good and safe to ride on, lot's of well preserved Spanish architecture, and the average house there is quite big and neat looking for Filipino standard. Some people even built houses in the native vernacular style but with modern materials.

Supremely c o m f y. 10/10 would recommend everyone
Only drawback is that there are quite a bit more mosquitos and those tiny flies that bite you than what you are usually expecting.

Public transportation makes no sense when the population density is peanuts to begin with. Ireland has fuck all in terms of population and the roads they have are enough for the few commuting sheep shaggers they have to deal with.
On the other hand, cities like Paris or London have had this problem for more than a century and that is precisely why they were the first to have a metro network.

Public transportation is only good in theory, but in practice, the services are never improved and just kept at tolerable levels of function because there is no real free market (and the existence of cars are ironically the only thing that brings some self regulation to the table), and population density is regulated by limiting the size of buildings therefore forcing people to live in the suburbs where public transports becomes very inefficient very fast (due to the surface covered following a square law). In other words, public transportation works when you have densely populated commie blocks in which cars/scooters are a realistic alternative when shit goes down. In other words, east asian cities.

In other words, public transportation needs cars. Cars don't need public transportation. i.e, public transportation is shit. If you can't commute to your job by car, you're in the wrong city.


Induced demand is a retarded concept. We just don't have enough lanes and we just didn't push our cities to be made FOR cars rather than this grotesque hybrid shit that is currently going on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Just spent two months nomading in Singapore so I can answer some of your questions.

My budget is on the high end, but if you moved here long term rent is pretty reasonable compared to other tier 1 cities. You are looking at 1500-2500 a month for something decent.

The weather is basically the same all the time, varies how much it rains and every time you step outside you get hit with the humidity. It's definitely bearable but probably the number one complaint

The city is highly efficient and clean, no homeless, no theft. You can leave your laptop at Starbucks for 8 hours and come find it in the same spot.

The food is world class rank 1, at least in terms of Asian food. You have a large mix of everyone giving you a tonne of variety in regional dishes.

The biggest thing is everyone speaks English. Kind of scuffed English but English nonetheless. As such you can small chat everyone and make friends/date locals pretty easily. No need to worry about gaijin hunters or whatever the fuck.

Since you can speak with them, you can see the soul of the people here. Unfortunately it's been stripped away by some auth-dystopian capitalistic society. The strictness, the mandatory military service, creates a very servile population. Most people here are extremely sterile and boring, set in their goals (job, marriage, kids). Coming from any western society it's actually really jarring how close minded everyone is. I dated a lot as well and came up with the same result, I don't recommend you get into anything serious with anyone here unless you want a boring life with a boring partner.

The island is pretty small, if you live in a normal city anywhere else in the world you have the option to take a drive, train, or whatever to go do some bullshit in the countryside. Here you are mostly always in urban hell. It is a good hub to the rest of the region though.

Anyways you shouldn't live here unless you make at least 80k a year.

Do you plan to have an income during your two nomadic years? Have you graduated university or some kind of training program, or have plans to do something like that when you return?
If I was in your position, I'd be very tempted to travel around for a couple of years and enjoy life. And I won't try to dissuade you because I'd probably still do it. My suggestions are to set a monthly budget for yourself (or a longer time frame budget if you're going to different CoL countries) and have a plan for what you're going to do when you return. You don't want to burn through your money and come back and have no realistic plan to get more money/earn a living.
Don't rely on the idea your parents/family will be there to bail you out and let you move back home and eat their meals without paying anything. A lot can change in the two years you're gone.

It's possible but a much bigger pita. You'll need to spend a couple of hours just building a bivouac to protect you from raib/snow. Tl:dr; it's possible if you have accomplished cold-weather survival skills.

>>2401599
Bishkek is a comfortable city to live in as an expat. Small, but big enough that it's got most everything you could want, plus beautiful mountains less than an hour away. Kyrgyzstan is just lovely in general.

In Kazakhstan I in Ust Kamenogorsk, a provincial city whose economy is based on metallurgy and mining. The atmosphere was completely different from Bishkek. It's 50% Russian and 50% Kazakh, and even the Kazakhs are quite Russified. The city is closer culturally and geographically to the cities of southwestern Siberia than Central Asia. There's a huge wealth gap and most people are in poor health because of pollution from heavy industry. The city itself doesnt have much charm. However, East Kazakhstan as a whole is a fascinating place with plenty of beautiful landscapes and interesting people. It's right where the steppe meets the Altai, so there's plenty to explore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402145
It's very easy. You only need to use two buttons, which I have circled in red.
Say you want to colour a specific region light red, you click the tool that I marked B, and you'll see your cursor takes the shape of that tool. Then you left click the colour you want to use, i.e. the big circle. You'll notice that colour 1, which I marked C, changes to light red.
If you repeat this process but you RIGHT click a coloured circle instead of left clicking it, you will select the colour as colour 2. Let's click dark red. This way you can have both shades of red selected at the same time, which makes colouring in the map more convenient, especially when doing big countries.
Now you select the tool which I marked A. Let's get to colouring. Say you want to colour Indiana in light red and you want to colour Ohio in dark red. Easy. Left click Indiana and right click Ohio.

Maybe we can make a standardised OP with these instructions (and the template).
I think the use of the colours is pretty self explanatory, even though I always see people mess it up. But people can use the map how they want to, so I don't think we have to tell anyone how they should colour their map. The colours are more like suggestions. You don't have to use these colours, and you don't have to use all of them. When and how you use them is up to your interpretation only.

>>2402196
My father is married to a Burkinese woman who moved here 15y ago and is perfectly integrated. We visited her family in Ouagadougou 11y ago for a period of 3 weeks in July. We went to the city center a few times and also to some smaller suburbs. Also went swimming a few times and to a wildlife parc. The only paved roads I saw were in the center. The suburbs only had dirtroads and traffic rules are non existent. Most of our activities were staying inside and chatting with people though.

People are very nice over there, but you stand out alot as a white person. We were regularly swarmed by kids who wanted to touch our skin and shake hands.

During the day it's hot af and going outside during noon was hell for us. At night you had to watch out for mosquitos and sleep under a veil or a ventilator.

The best thing I remember was the food. Fresh fruit like mangos and baked bananas in a spicy sauce with some rice. The water strangely came in plastic bags instead of bottles and you had to bite open one of the edges before drinking.

>>2402870
Only in Brussels, which we all avoid like the plague
>>2402880
The Ardennes have some nice hiking trails if you're into that. I especially enjoyed the one that starts at the top of Signal de Botrange, the highest peak in Belgium. De Hoge Venen in general are nice, take a break in Spa if you find yourself nearby.
Antwerp has a nice historical centre and a massive shopping street if you're bringing a gf. A bicycle trip along the Damse Vaart from Bruges to Sluis is also nice if you want something sporty.
Tongeren has a Roman museum since there was a big settlement there in Roman times. Bastogne has a big war museum commemorating the Battle of the Bulge.
If you're in Ghent, go to the Vrijdagsmarkt on a thursday night if you want the full nightlife experience, it's where the locals frequent. Most of Ghent's massive student population parties in the Overpoort but it's highly overrated and smells like piss and vomit from a mile away, would not recommend unless you're into 18 year olds.
Bruges is mainly a tourist hotspot with not many locals unlike Ghent, which makes it feel a bit more artificial but still filled with beautiful medieval architecture, so still worth seeing.
Brussels is a shit city, don't visit.

What are the chances of there being 3 anons from the same small Belgian province in one thread? Crazy stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2406684
Oh, a fellow train enthusiast!
If you have time then I would recommend you to do a detour via Uzbekistan since the train from Mangystau (on the Caspian Sea) to Almaty will be three days of desert turning into steppe without much else to see.
If going via Uzbekistan you can see Karakalpakstan (both the capital Nukus and the former fishing town of Muynak known for the stranded fishing vessels), further down you can take a look at the Silk Road cities of Khiva/Bukhara/Samarkand, all depending on your schedule.
From Tashkent you can then take the 001 to Almaty, probably the fanciest train in Central Asia.

If you're adamant about staying only in Kazakhstan, then you should do a stop in Turkestan or Taraz, both to freshen up and to see some ancient buildings and how the Kazakhs try to build up tourism. Plenty of trains from there to Almaty, so no need to worry about losing too much time.
If the international trains from to China haven't started again by the time of your trip then you might want to see if you can cross into China via the Khorgos SEZ for a view into the modern trade routes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2406684
Oh, and if Azerbaijan still fusses around by the time of your trip, you can easily fly to Aktau as a backup measure, FlyArystan is not indexed on the usual flight search engines but has many low-cost flights in the region.

the dark green snake that goes all the way to bali is a year long trip i took from germany to there overland. took a ferry from bulgaria to georgia over the black sea and on from singapore to jakarta to explain the gaps. the rest is just individual trips for holiday. i never drove a vehicle myself just hitchhiked alot mostly in the european part. then took alot of sleeper trains, buses, taxis etc.

Armenia is based. One of my favourite countries of the entire trip. Hitchhiking works great there. Got picked up by family who showed us some castles and villages.Great people. Sewan Lake has chill vibes. Good Hiking opportunities in the north if you are into that sort of thing. You're gonna have a blast.

>>2399005
The list of vaccines you probably need to be prudent goes down if you're staying in cities. Assuming you got your childhood vaccinations (MMR, DTaP, Polio), the most important are Hep A/B and Typhoid. You should get Tetanus booster as well unless you had a booster within the last 10 years (you probably had one at 12 years old). If you're going to Cambodia, also consider Cholera vaccination, which is a drinkable vaccine and gives some protection against food poisoning too.
If you plan on spending time in the countryside, you should get Japanese Encephalitis and strongly consider getting 3 shot Rabies PREP. (You'll still need to get any risky animal encounters treated but getting the 3 shots in advance will stop your trip from being ruined and might save your life if you don't get any further treatment.) These shots are really expensive in Western countries but they're cheap if you get them in SEA.
And rather than taking advice from randoms on the Internet, you should visit a travel medicine doctor. They'll try to sell you on a lot more vaccines than you probably need, but they'll rank their importance depending on your destinations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2399245
>How is it with cash? Is it necessary or can you function with just a card?
You can do almost everything with a card. Mid-sized and bigger restaurants will take it, use booking sites to do all your hotel reservations, convenience and grocery stores will do Apple Pay, Grab and Food Panda can use a card, etc. (Grab can be picky with your card - it will need to be one that can do security authorization PINs.) You'll need cash for street and cheap restaurants, most bars, night markets, prozzies, etc.
>Any services to specifically take/avoid? (especially getting from the airport to hotel, how do I not get scammed/overcharged?)
Fly in BKK and take the metro in the basement of the airport directly into the city. You'll probably take it to Phaya Thai, where you walk through a connecting tunnel to connect to the BTS. Make sure your hotel is near a BTS or MTS station.
Don't use taxis. They've gotten better in recent years but you'll always have less problems sticking with Grab.
Whenever someone tries to sell you something, say "my krop". The "my" part means "no" and "krop" is a respectful word that makes anything polite. (Women say "ka" - don't imitate female Thai or you'll be a joke.) Adding "krop" takes the edge off anything you say, and even a drunken Thai looking to start something will probably look elsewhere
>Are there any cooming forums? I have read bits here, but would like to read up on experiences and places more so I know what im getting into.
I forget their names. Just google.
>Can I find a reasonably priced hotel with a gym/pool or are those only the upper tier ones?
Easier to find hotels with pools than gyms, and the gyms are usually shit. If you're lucky, there will be some machines that max out low. Look for 4 star hotels.
>How is tinder/other apps in there? Do the girls speak english enough to hold a convo?
Thailand is life on easy mode. Pay for Tinder Gold, set your profile to Bangkok and just wait for the matches to roll in.

The cost of living difference between Cambodia, Vietnam, and Thailand comes down to a few dollars per day. (This can vary between cities but is mostly true for the countryside.) There are big differences when you go really cheap (bare bones survival is cheapest in Cambodia) or still want some luxuries (standard of living rises fastest in Thailand compared to additional costs).
It would be better for you to give what you want your daily or monthly budget to be, and some of us can probably tell you what you can expect in different countries at that level.
If you have "a few thousand" ($3000?) and want to get away for "a few months" (3 months?) then you can live quite well anywhere in the region on $1000/month as long as you get out of the tourist/expat ghettos.

>>2401364
It's hard to tell someone who wants to stretch their money how far they can stretch it in SEA. If you've never been in a developing country before (or even if you have), you might be the type of person who wants to stay in a comfortable bubble - restaurants with English menus, hotels with air conditioning and hot water close to restaurants/bars, taking taxis/Grab instead of figuring out local buses, etc. If you use mid-range hostels or the cheapest hotels, order Food Panda and local restaurants for most of your meals, and limit drinking alcohol is bars and restaurants, you can get by with a budget of $20-30/day (half of that on rent), depending where you are. This doesn't include travel costs to move around.
The best way to bring that down further is to find a long term place to stay. You're probably not going to want to sign a lease, so the low-hanging fruit is to look for share houses and rooms on Facebook and maybe local expat forums, depending on the country. Realistically, expect to pay about $200/month for something simple and shared. You can certainly get cheaper but the really cheap places aren't advertised by other expats or on FB.
Food can get brought down if you cook your own food, or if you learn to eat where locals eat. Think $1/meal. Add in extra expenses and you can skint your way down to $500/month budget.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2401510
Now the next problem is your visa costs. Looking at Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam, all of these countries technically only allow 30 days upon entry. (I think Thailand is currently 45.) Thailand has free entry for most passports, Cambodia is $36, Vietnam is $25. Taking a bus between these countries is currently $25-35 one way.
In Thailand, you can extend your visa-free entry by another 30 days for $55 without leaving the country. In Cambodia you can extend another 30 days for about $35 without leaving the country. You can't currently extend in Vietnam. You can leave and re-enter Thailand twice by land borders every calendar year, unlimited times by air, but there's always the chance that Thai immigration will turn you back. One way to lessen this is to pay for a 60 day single entry visa (which can also be extended for 30 days without leaving the country) or a 180 day ME visa (which has more application requirements and a big cost). You can do visa runs with Cambodia and Vietnam indefinitely - they don't care.
So on the surface it will seem you can spend the most time in Thailand without doing expensive border runs, but Thailand is the country that's harder to live skint. Their whole economy is designed to suck money from farang, and even in remote areas you'll find yourself getting gouged and being resented if you barter too hard. There are places you can still do it (Chiang Mai and Chiang Rai are very budget and backpacker friendly, along with almost all the north). And if you get a Thai gf, which will be inevitable unless your tastes lean towards men or katoey, she will show you how to make your money go further.
Cambodia and Vietnam are easier to live on a budget, in my opinion, for various reasons. Don't expect as smooth an experience getting to different parts of them by local transport. But you can live in hotels in Siem Reap or Hoi An, eat meals in restaurants with English menus, and drink $0.5-1.00 beers in bars on about $20/day.

>Is sildenafil causing hearing loss a real risk?
Interesting thread to bring this up in. There is no conclusive research, but there is a strong correlation between older men who use sildenafil being twice as likely as men the same age to show some hearing loss. There's a theory that the same mechanism of sildenafil that makes blood flow easier could also affect the longevity of ear hair follicles that are used for hearing. Using a high dose of sildenafil daily would put a similar strain on your hearing as working in a loud environment. But this is just a theory because it doesn't seem to affect all men the same way. There might be a genetic factor because, for whatever reason, it seems to happen more to men in the US population than in the UK and Europe.
A sudden onset of loss of hearing after using sildenafil is rare, usually affects one ear, and appears within 24 hours. It's a rare side effect - about as common as getting priapism from sildenafil. It's thought to be reversible if you get medical attention soon enough. Treatment involves high doses of Medrol for a week to bring down inflammation in the affected ear.

>>2404823
Try Mango rentals near Nimman, they've sometimes got a few beefier bikes that are a slight step up from scooters but not quite big bike territory. If you want big adventure bikes there's some place on the east side of the old city moat but prices are typically steep.

Mango owner is a nice English dude. No fuckery with ripping you off but the mechanics are Thai so before you sign make sure the break pads are still decent and whatnot. I rented a Kawasaki 175 from them for a month a few years back and did the drive to Pai, bike held up great. Going up to mae hong son you're gonna have a bad time on an automatic. Thais will do it but they're all retarded anyway. There's a lot of up and down on that road so you'll want a machine with gears and engine braking otherwise you'll burn up your brakes pretty quick.

Also don't be like me and do that road with 0 experience on a bike. At 2 spots I very nearly slid into a ditch. There's a Honda driving school about 30 minutes out of town that's really great, full day courses and you can reserve from a big selection of Honda bikes. You can also do the Samoeng and Mae Rim loop to warm up a few times.

Good luck, you're gonna have a great time

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2406861
I just spent a week in Malaysia.
Georgetown has nice heritage streets and really good food. Penang Hill is a nice day trip with great views and the opportunity to see some wildlife like monkeys. The nearby Kek Lok Si is quite nice, ideally come during the lunar new year period to see it light up at night, likewise there are nice neat activities in georgetown during this period - unfortunately that's all just passed so you'd be waiting a year.
Langkawi is a group of islands north of Penang which are apparently a nice beach destination, I didn't go though.
I also spent some time in KL. There are some nice sights but overall it's just Asian New York. It's fine for a short visit but I wouldn't spend too long there.
The other main tourist sights on the peninsula are the Cameron Highlands and Malacca. I didn't bother because they didn't look that interesting but if I'd had more time I would have gone.
From what I understand Borneo is basically just nature tourism like mountain hikes and seeing orangutans. Kuching is the main city people visit.
I liked Malaysia overall but its a particular type of destination - it's neighbors beat it in beaches and night-life but it does have good food and a medley of regional cultures to experience. A big plus is that English very widespread.
If you can afford it you may as well go to Singapore as well for a short trip. Its not amazing but it's worth a brief stint in my opinion.

Starting to think we collectively develop an FAQ like the Japan general for this stuff - I don't mean anything bad by that, but post pandemic we're getting enough questions like this it may be helpful.
To answer your question, it's really up to you and what you want to see. The only "island" nation per se is Singapore, Indonesia and the Philippines are huge so it doesn't really matter that they're islands in comparison to the mainland countries.
If you mean should you go to tropical islands for a beach holiday, typically Thailand is your best bet but every SEA country other than Laos and the microstates have solid options. It's really up to you if you want to go to islands or inland you can do both if you like.
For the smaller islands typically you get ferries from the mainland. If you mean between the major islands in Indonesia or the Philippines, ferries are often an options but flights are a better choice for longer distances.
I'd probably suggest a Thailand holiday so you can experience both inland options and nice islands, but you could go almost anywhere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hey OP, am also half and half

I was making 200-400rmb an hour in Beijing 2015-2017 as a full-time student. However that was mainly through private lessons, working under the table at a tutoring center, etc..

Basically I'd get a part-time job, work at it for a bit, guanxi with parents, and cut out the middleman. Turn those 150/hr tutoring jobs into 300. Parents and students were fine with my 'racial ambiguity'.

The only time I felt slighted was getting hired for a high school speech course. The pay was good at 500rmb/hr pathed up to a work visa, and too good to be true. Right as classes started the coordinator dropped me from 5 classes to 1 and told me I'd be a substitute teacher. They told me I shouldn't have gotten the job on paper (Chinese last name) but was handsome enough to make it work. Some jobs aren't worth taking

I don't know how flexible the situation is with Student Visa's nowadays but basically everyone I knew who studied hard in China was working on the side. I knew this Bangladeshi guy with a London accent who taught over Wechat. 2 hours a night at 300rmb/hr teaching people barely able to string a sentence together.

At one point I also did apply for a formal workvisa / classroom monkey job, but you have to fight for every bit and piece of your contract. It's always a headache with contracts.

Already spending too much time on this OP, but tldr Parents and Students like mixed-race, schools and companies will use it to bargain against you.

Anyway that's my experiences OP, best of luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2407209
Not the anons your replied to I'm
>>2406809
But there are essentially 2 types of lounges, the first are airline lounges which you get entry to if you're flying business or first class or if you're of a certain status with airlines. These lounges never deny access if you have an eligible ticket - very rarely some airlines allow you to pay for entry but it's down to how busy it is.
The other type is the "pay" lounges, there's usually a few different ones at each airport and theyre all very hit & miss. You gain entry to these with certain cards you can get from your bank as other anons have said or you can pay for an annual membership. The difference is that having a card doesn't guarantee entry, as these lounges sell access online and in person it's a first come first served based on capacity but as I said in my earlier post, as you're not buying access to 1 particular lounge with your membership these have become pretty shit - they're not really bothered about "repeat business" so the standards have dropped massively over the years.
I've used both in my time and I would say a lounge is a good idea even if you have to pay for it, you get away from the crowds and if you take into account the amount you spend on food & drink waiting for a flight it's worth it if you can find a good one

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2405827
Hundred yen stores. By the way, you'll need to use the Japan post website to print out a shipping label because Japan will not just let you write the address on the box anymore. You can print out the label at a convenience store. They have photocopy machines. And when you fill out the info you have to be exact on the weight and describing the contents. If you just describe it as "toy" or "collectable" they'll tell you to go and do the entire process all over again. So make sure you weigh it, describe it as "super embarassing creepy anime bullshit," and put the monetary value on the insurance claim form. Set aside a few hours to do all this and never use Japan post again.

An update from the last thread in regards to the Platt Kotodama train.

I tried to get a ticket but its the same price as a regular Shinkansen ticket. The only difference now is that its an hour slower and stops at more places. So if you are going from Tokyo to Osaka, your options are Shinkansen as most expensive but easiest. Domestic flight thats less time in a chair and cheaper but requires more logistics, or theres the night bus which is the cheapest, slowest option. The sleeper train really only seems like an option if you just really want to experience it or you need an overnight when planes or trains arent running and maybe cant or wont take the bus.

As far as the crime, its still pretty rare but its been happening for a long time. People are still evil by nature. Babbys stuffed in coin lockers, those guys who raped that girl with a lightbulb etc etc. You can be a woman and generally be pretty safe walking at night more so than other countries, but you can't 100% let your guard down. I feel safe and like there aren't lots of thieves, but things can still happen, its just more rare here than Detroit.

There are definitely people that get rubbed the wrong way once and its over. I don't want to be that American nor do I want another American to be the reason some Jap decides "no foreigners allowed in this Isakaya" or some other second order effect.

Obviously theres nothing I can really do to help it much, but something as simple as a post on here like "dont bring cologne with you and buy deoderant as soon as you land" can be good advice. Normally I wouldn't care too much if it was any other country, but Japan is the only place I have ever been that will basically explicitly deny you from entering a restaurant or business just on the grounds you are a foreigner.

Korea has way better girls, level of English and most apps aren't banned there. Unfortunately people are unfriendly as fuck which is the opposite of China where people are rude but friendly as fuck. Korean cuisine is more westerner which I like but they also absorbed some of the worst aspects of American cuisine by adopting fucking spam and American cheese in their diets. The people are also INCREDIBLY focused on "face". I hear this "face" meme a lot for China but Korea takes it to another level, hell it ain't even that bad in China. >What about the trains
Both are excellent but different. The main difference between the two is that Seoul and most Korean cities seem like a tier 2 Chinese cities. You can't compare Seoul to Shanghai or Chengdu. Everything in Korea just seems so much smaller because it is. In China you can go to the desert, a rain forest, the grasslands, the beach. Etc. In Korea you essentially just have Jeju (which the locals won't shut up about because that's all they have.
If you have two weeks, go to Korea. If you have two months, go to China. There is just way more to see in China. Don't go to China is you want to relax nor if it's your first time travelling. You will have a terrible time.

>>2403552
I lived in Chongqing and Xi'an. There are barely any white people in these cities. Sometimes I would have to go to smaller cities for extra work. During the winter and summer holidays (where I got like two months off) I would visit as many places as possible.
>what about foreigner prices?
there are so few foreigners in China that this barely even exists as a concept. 20 years ago it did but most Chinese dont see white people are rich anymore. They'll just charge you the normal price. In the REALLY touristy areas of Shanghai or Beijing this probably happens but I dont know as I dont really go to those places. In BJ I went to some super touristy markets cause my mom came to visit me but it all turned out fine. There are some old granny markets you can go to where you are suppose to bargain with them, but I doubt the average tourist will go to these places.
>you skipped the morning markets
My life was all about the markets. You seriously think they are going to overcharge me for jianbing when all the prices are on signs? After 1 year living there you start to get a feel for what the prices are and I never felt taken advantage of. You have to be a true top tier idiot to fall for any scams because they are obvious as fuck. The scams you'll encounter are beautiful girls on Tantan asking you to meet them but you have to pay for their taxi, Shanghai taxis or buying a "Chamel" bag/perfume from some street vendor thinking its legit. The only real worries I had in China were about air quality as eastern coastal cities moved all their factories inland making Chengdu and Chongqing air pollution shitholes (though if you want to visit BJ and Shanghai you'll be pleasantly surprised about how good the air is now) also you have to be aware of the bad food quality in China. While the gutter oil problem is overstated, it hasn't been completely eradicated either.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2401509
Didn't really have any profound realizations, but traveling definitely helped me develop.

I've been using /trv/ since about 2012 and took my first-ever overseas trip in 2013. I was, at the time, a reasonably attractive but incredibly awkward, borderline autistic sperg. I had no social confidence, was intimidated by women, and could barely hold a conversation with other men. Looking back, I don't think I had any hobbies outside of reading books and playing video games. I was, overall, a very boring, sterile person.

Everything started changing after my first trip, which took me to:
>Turkey
>Greece
>Iraq
>Georgia
>Armenia
>the UAE
>India
>Kazakhstan

Since I often had to interact with people in completely different languages, I quickly shed my fear of social rejection. I also drank for the first time, had my first few hook-ups, and got involved in what turned out to be a very, very bad long-distance relationship.

I kept traveling after that and have been to somewhere between 50-60 countries. Traveling exposed me to a lot of new interests: I learned to speak two languages--Hindi to fluency, and Turkish to the B2 level--started riding motorcycles, and came up with a dissertation topic for my doctorate.

No idea how I'd have turned out if I wasn't a /trv/tard, but I'm pretty happy with my present life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Traveling helped me develop a life philosophy based around the fact that life sucks everywhere as much as it can be good.
Living anywhere will always have pluses and minuses and the sum of both will, as a rule, tend towards zero. It's all up to how you subjectively weight these factors.
I've lived in and interacted with people, both locals and expats in many places from 1st to 3rd world and everywhere follows the same rule. Numbers such as GDP per capita or HDI do play a role in how "livable" a place is, but there's plenty of invisible things, including culture, language, mentality that will make or break it for one person or the other.
Living abroad is exaggeratedly romanticised as much as sticking to your home country due to some misplaced patriotism is. I have grown to live without attachments to a particular place, just being able to objectively embrace and enjoy/suffer all the highs and lows each particular place has to offer.

>>2401509

1. That traveling primarily for tourism leads to major disappointment & boredom. I truly believe you should have a primary reason for travel (business, fieldwork, volunteering, language immersion, education, friends/family, cooming, photojournalism, etc.) and the tooorism part should come secondary. It's more fun when the expectations are lower.

2. As a friendless introvert, traveling alone actually isn't always *that* great. The most tragic thing is that I've had my best experiences when I've travelled with annoying, headstrong, immature people who get you into the craziest situations that I otherwise would be uncharismatic & cautious to get into, and I have wild stories to tell back home and write about. Isn't that what it's all about? Let's be honest.

3. Americanized ethnic food is always superior. I've sought the most authentic places in Italy, Mexico, France, China, and so on, and it's always mid. Sorry but it's just the truth. Yes we put a lot of crap in it, but the taste is undeniably better. Those food tour travel vloggers are being facetious and clickbaity when they rave about local foods.

4. With that said, America has its problems, but I am always relieved to be back home. Even after staying in the nicest towns in Europe. This country was designed for comfort/convenience over aesthetics/culture. There are only a few places that aren't cookie cutter outlet malls. Sometimes I wish to have my air conditioning, elbow room, ice, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: I did the digital nomad thing in Europe and here's what I think
posts.com:
It's fucking lonely, that's the main thing. You can't build meaningful relationships, you can't establish a home base, you can only travel with a small amount of items, language barriers are a killer (even in English-strong countries), and the hassle of moving place to place, vetting long-term rentals, meeting hosts, etc consumes much more time than you'd think. It's great to travel, and I do love the aspect of doing that. But I think it's better to travel to places 1-2 weeks at a time with a girlfriend/friend with a proper hotel than do this.

Now I want to share my perspective as an American. These past few months have also made me more grateful for being an American. I like Europe, especially Vienna, my favorite city besides Reykjavik, but America is better in many more ways than I realized. People are nicer, food is better (I didn't actually thing this would be true but it is. I'm in Italy and all I can think about is how the Italian food in America is better), dating is easier (European women are strange, still figuring them out), alcohol is WAY better. I also miss private car use more than I thought I would, car-based infrastructure can be ugly but with a car, you really can go anywhere without having to wait for the tram/bus.

There are definitely objectively better parts of Europe though, namely coffee, history, food quality (as in ingredients rather than taste in this case), city safety (this is a big one, you can mostly relax in European cities while in America you always have to look over your shoulder), demographics, museums (but that's more useful to a tourist than a resident), infrastructure quality, and some other things.

So I'm torn. One thing I know is that I can't keep doing this moving around thing, I need a place to call home. My actual home (North Carolina) is pretty great, but I would love to live in Vienna longer term. Thing is, I have no clue how to get a visa that lets me stay longer. Anyway, I'm out of space, thanks for reading my blog.

Q: What medications help with schizophrenia?

A: Antipsychotic medications are the most commonly prescribed drugs for treating schizophrenia. These medications are designed to reduce the symptoms associated with schizophrenia, including delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized speech and behavior. Commonly prescribed antipsychotics include risperidone (Risperdal), aripiprazole (Abilify), clozapine (Clozaril), quetiapine (Seroquel), olanzapine (Zyprexa), paliperidone (Invega), ziprasidone (Geodon), and lurasidone (Latuda). Side effects of these medications may include sedation, weight gain, and movement disorders. It is important to discuss with your doctor any potential side effects and risks associated with these medications before beginning treatment.

Q: what other treatments for schizophrenia exists besides medicine?

A: In addition to medications, there are several other treatments that can help with managing schizophrenia symptoms. These include cognitive-behavioral therapy, family therapy, supportive psychotherapy, and social skills training. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) helps individuals identify and change dysfunctional thinking patterns and behavior. Family therapy helps family members learn to better support the person with schizophrenia, build stronger relationships, and improve communication. Supportive psychotherapy helps people with schizophrenia cope with stress, identify and manage symptoms, and develop social skills. Social skills training helps individuals with schizophrenia learn how to interact with others more effectively.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2405436
Stay in hostels, it's simply the easiest way to make a good trip a great trip.
You will meet a ton of people in them, often you can ask them about places to go or sometimes people will just invite you to places. Don't listen to the myths about hostels only being for hippy stoners or weird old guys; there's all sorts of people in them and that is part of the fun, I have met full time investors and people that are travelling to play in gaming competitions on my trips. staying around new people will also improve your social skills immensely which a lot of people on this website can do with.
On the other hand not all hostels are made equal, some are small and quiet and some are huge and never stop the music, I prefer something in the middle so read the reviews before booking.

>What to pack
Clothing obviously depends on location (do you really need a down jacket in the tropics?) but typically bring enough clothes for like 5 or 6 days. Other countries wash their clothes too, and in a pinch, washing your clothes in the sink or shower is totally fine.
Leave the nintendo switch and the ipad at home. Your phone is enough and if you're going for a long time or maybe working while traveling, a small laptop. Power adapter and phone battery pack are a must.

>Luggage
Skip the wheeled suitcases, they WILL become cumbersome and annoying, use only a backpack. Put some other personal bag in your backpack like a tote bag or sling for you to use daily. Osprey has a good range of backpacks, if you are only travelling for a couple weeks than carry-on only is totally possible, otherwise a slightly larger bag may be needed.

>Websites
Booking for accomodation
Rome2Rio for transport
SkyScanner for flights

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2407178
My other tips

-Be spontaneous. If someone invites you to do something cool, you should probably do it even if you didn't have it in your plans.
-Don't try to do too much, a lot of people have this problem and try to cram all of Europe into a 2 week trip.
-Keep a low profile, avoid standing out too much. Especially in more conservative countries like the middle east or japan, don't be the "loudmouth westerner" just smile and be polite. Don't be too loud and annoy locals, they will like you more.
-Do local things such as use public transport, eat local foods, go to the supermarket. I really enjoy going to the supermarket and buying some food and making my own meals, it helps me save money and eating out at restaurants every meal gets tiring.
-If you like saving money, look for overnight transport options. Overnight buses or boats are common in many countries and get you accommodation and transport in 1.
-Don't be a picky eater, if you are just know that I have a very low opinion of you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I went to Italy in the summer. Went from the north down to the south. At first the north was nice, cleaner than I expected, whiter than I expected, and extremely friendly and helpful people. Very nice place.

The south though? I will never forget it. I have never experienced anything like the Amalfi coast before. It felt surreal. It felt like a dream. It felt like I was on mushrooms. The sheer beauty of the land was hard to deal with. Every five minutes I'd be faced with the most beautiful landscape I'd ever seen. I know on my deathbed I will remember my drive from Naples to Positano along those winding volcano roads. No other experience I've had on this planet can compare to that in terms of sheer natural beauty.

Naples itself was kind of a dump, very rundown and grimy which was very off-putting at first but after growing accustomed to it it became charming in a way. And I will always have love for Naples based on nothing more than the pizza, which, over the course of a three country two week trip throughout Europe was BY FAR the best food we ate. It was stunning how cheap and amazing the food was. At a plastic table where I brushed cigarette ash off of my plate and Indian kids screamed wildly in the streets, where haggard old women hung out of windows smoking and scooters zipped around dangerously, I had the best meal in my entire life.

Italy is amazing. The south of Italy is beyond amazing.

I just did a week in Zermatt for a snowboard trip. It was the most expensive place I have ever been in my entire life, and also one of the most beautiful. As others said, the food is definitely not as good as France and Italy. Nearly everyone we met was a tourist or a seasonal worker from some other country. The Matterhorn and the surrounding mountains are unreal. It was cold as shit the week we were there, but the snow was good. The ski trails were too difficult for my wife, but I had a good time. The town is pristine. Every spot in town looks like a postcard.

Would I recommend visiting? Yes...but only if you have plenty of money saved up for the trip. We never ate out once for less than $100. We spent $400 for 2 roundtrip train tickets from Geneva to Zermatt. Snowboard and boot rental were $100 per day, not including the lift ticket. We ran into tourists from South America who couldn't afford to get a beer in the bars because they were $12.
If I ever go back, it'll be in the summer. If I snowboard again in Europe, it'll be on the French or Italian side, or possibly in Slovenia.

Switzerland is absolutely worth a visit, but you should have a high budget to actually enjoy your time there since basically everything costs twice as much as it does in surrounding countries. Longer stays are best done in alpine austria (almost as beautiful), northern Italy, and southeastern France because you'll save a shitton more money and enjoy around 80% of the experience. I come from a fairly well-off family in the States, and even I felt like a pauper walking the streets of Lucerne and Lugano. >>2406382
I never crossed over into Italy when I was boarding, but it was open. It was insanely cold that week and I didn't want to risk getting stuck on the Italian side with my wife back in Zermatt. It was -17 C on the mountain all week.

Renting snowboarding gear outside of Zermatt and hauling it on the train would have been really inconvenient. We saw other people doing it and it looked terrible. Hauling that shit on the train would not have been worth the $100 we would have saved. The best thing about Zermatt is that you don't wait in line for snowboarding. We never waited for a single person to board a gondola or eat out anywhere. The photo looks crowded because that was where everyone stopped to take photos on the mountain. The run from the top was 14 miles. There were sections where I wouldn't see anyone else for 10 minutes.

The mountain infrastructure in Switzerland is incredible. Every peak has a giant gondola. Zermatt had a train and a gondola that takes you to the top. The train system wasn't as fast as Italy, but they were really nice and never very crowded. The train route from Geneva to Zermatt was amazing. The views are insane.

>>2406435
Sure. You could save money and not eat out, or stay in a smaller place, but why go to Switzerland then? If you're in a budget, go to the Alps in France or Italy. We had a huge Airbnb in the middle of Zermatt that was the entire third floor of a building. It was $200 a night. not cheap, but way better than the tony hotel rooms in town that were same price or more. We did stay in a hotel for 2 nights in Geneva. Switzerland has the smallest hotel rooms I've ever seen. I also think it's fair to mention that a fondue meal for 2 in Switzerland at a decent restaurant is going to run you $150. Or that bars charge $18+ for a mixed drink. I bought a couple $25 Mai Tais at the Grand Hotel that were worth every penny.

>>2405743
Travel can be cheap if you do it right (especially if you live somewhere with a lot of different countries nearby, like Europe). Most of my shorter international trips cost $100-200, including accommodation, flights, airport parking, gasoline, food, entertainment etc. The price per day goes down the longer the trip is too (since the flights become a smaller part of the total), so if you have more patience than me and travel for longer periods instead of several small trips you could save even more. Better yet, travel with a vehicle like a car, moped or bicycle to cut down on transportation costs.

>North Macedonia, 3 days for $94
>Albania, 3 days for $120
>Albania, 8 days for $280
>Hungary, 3 days for $190

Btw, I'm currently in high school lmao, I just save a lot of money from some freelancing work I do and can travel several times a year whenever we have an off day or break from school. Granted, I don't have to pay for housing, utilities or food when I live at home so it may be harder for those who do, but my income is also tiny, so I think most people should be able to make it work.

posts.com: Retard here. Let’s say I want to sleep at a hotel starting Sunday night but I’m leaving the hotel Wednesday morning, do I book Sunday to Tuesday?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: No, you typically book hotels "per night" so that would be Sunday, Monday and Tuesday night, meaning you would check out Wednesday morning. So the booking would say Sunday-Wednesday.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You're paying per night so, hypothetical scenario (4pm check-in time/11am checkout time assuming)

Sunday 4pm/Monday morning is a night
Monday 4pm/Tuesday morning is night
Tuesday 4pm/Wednesday 11am is the third night

Sunday 4pm-Wednesday 11am, three nights

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Three options here

1. Tell them you aren't sure exactly when you will leave and if you will see another country after or go back home so you will book it soon, and show you have enough for that, no one has ever even asked me to show funds or ticket but I have a good passport
2. Find an airline that lets you reschedule without fees, and book a roundtrip. I know a lot of airlines did this during covid so I rescheduled a flight a fee times, but double check
3. Find a flight and print the information so it looks like you booked it, they do not check that you really did. Bring a proof of funds to be safe whichever way you choose.

>what country's nature impressed you

never really traveled much in other countries, but Hawaii impressed the hell out of me.

I went for a 10 day vacation, split between Maui and Kauai, and found it to be literal heaven on Earth.

Everything you expect from Hawaii is exactly what it is. The weather, the beaches, the forests and jungles, the rivers...

it felt to me like the cleanest outdoor experience i've ever encountered. In other places I've been, going to the river or beach can be a somewhat dirty and miserable experience, if you get wet you feel like shit. In Hawaii? You don't even really need a towel while exploring. You just dry off in like 10 minutes.

It's strikingly beautiful in every way. The air is cleaner than what continental Americans are accustomed to, the water is more pleasant, the people are far nicer. Honestly felt like every single person we met while traveling wanted us to have a fantastic time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2404449
I live in San Diego also. You can get a FLIGHT from Tijuana to Mexico City for under $100 round trip, booked in advance. Buses aren't much cheaper. Why would you take the bus? Unless its for the meme. It'll take days. There's a bus to La Paz & Cabo too, its about 24 hours straight from TJ.

You should be able to get decent meals at inexpensive local places for under 100 pesos/person. Along with the usual tacos and shit look for places that advertise "comida corrida" which is a lunch special with a fixed item that is usually cheap, meant for people who are on a lunch break. This is especially true the further you get from the US, goods and services get cheaper. You should be able to get decent, but not touristy hotels for $25-50/night in areas that are safe/on major routes but not "touristy." Hostels aren't super common but there are some in more touristy cities. There's also pensiones which is like a hostel style bed in a room (shared bathrooms) which should be under $20. Hotels may or may not have internet and it may or may not be fast. Mexico still has a culture of internet cafes, these will probably be full of kids playing online games but more places have internet now than 10 years ago when it was still rare.

I'm really surprised how few people here visit Mexico.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They're all inclusive resorts on the sea. The larger modern ships have an insane amount in them. They're comparable to Holiday camps like Butlins but I think those are UK only things so that may not be especially helpful.

Cruises in general skew older but Disney Cruises (and cheap line) trend towards families, Cunard trend to have the oldest people (and are more formal), Virgin are aimed at young couples (and being "not like other cruises"). Sex cruises will be full of old swingers or be gay focused. Lots of people go on cruises to make friends so if you're sociable and are able to strike up conversations you can end up finding a couple/group/family to enjoy it with. Some cruise lines offer Solo cruise matching facilities where you share a cabin with someone they think you'll get on with (not a hook up).

Day trips only show you a very limited amount of a location so try to avoid big city wide tours (you'll whizz through everything) and aim for more focused ones that are on one particular activity/location. Glacier focused cruises are very popular because of how suited they are to this (NCL is the company for those).

Most popular types:

>glacier
>European cities
>Caribbean beach cruises

Repositioning cruises are the ones to go for if you're looking for a cheap holiday that's focused on being on the boat. There are also cruises to nowhere that often happen when a new ship launches. Tend to be cheaper for solo cruises too.

Transatlantic boats are very different from coastal boats as they're designed for the rougher seas. Be very careful of getting a Europe to America cruise on a boat that isn't meant for transatlantic trips.

As far as I'm aware the only company running ocean liners is cundard. Also I'd like to add that westbound transitioning cruises are vastly superior to eastbound because you are going forward a few hours instead of back. Unlike flights it's done in one hour increments.

French Polynesian cruises are real nice, sometimes you can get them coming from hawaii or Australia/New Zealand. East Coast of South America is good too, start in Buenos Aires and end up in rio. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Why do you travel solo?
It is just better for me. I have friends that like to travel too, but my way of travel is IMO very incompatible. I dont like to plan much, dont really do the whole day to day itinerary. Also if I am solo, I can get more chill to talk to other travellers. When I travelled with my friends, I just talk to them, I wont try to communicate with other people.

>How has it changed your life being away by yourself for long periods of time?
I am more outgoing and talkative with other travellers than I am at home. They dont know me, so if I fuck up something, I wont probably meet them again. And I realise, that people forget my fuckups at home too, but still cant really get that in my mind.


>How do you deal with the loneliness?
I will admit, that my first big solo travel (3 months) went really bad. I went to New Zealand and travelled only north of auckland and then got really depressed that I spent 2,5 months just in Auckland and did nothing pretty much for the whole time.
Only went to local library or gym, sometimes to a party and that was it.
I had to fake my travel photos by downloading them from the internet just so I did not have to admit my family that I literally did nothing on the opposite side of the earth for that long.
Nowadays I really regret not pushing through that and travel more through this country, because I might not get another second try to do that in reality.
After that my solo travels went better and I deal with being solo much better. For me, even short talk with people during the day gives me more energy to travel more.

>>2402209
You pretty much described Nice and the surrounding area (Cannes, Antibes etc, basically the French Riviera and the "arrière-pays niçois").
Not the cheapest area of France, possibly one of the most expensive ones but nowhere as crazy as Paris, especially if you're not after some nice house with a view over the sea.
It has mountains within 20 minutes of driving, and 1.5-2 hours takes you to ski stations and national parks (and there are buses taking you there).
It's right next to Northern Italy, the climate is absolutely great most of the year.
There's nice architecture in the area, more job opportunities than in many areas of France, population is quite young as young people from all over France come work here.
Yes, it can get expensive, but it's still cheaper than Paris and it's still ok to live there if you don't get too close to the sea. The further you are from the sea, the cheaper it is.

>>2402209
You might consider Toulouse as well. It's the fourth largest city in the country (after Paris, Lyon, and Marseille). It's what passes for a tech hub in France, with AirBus and some startups around to provide jobs. It's a university town, so it has a very active nightlife. The bars around the Place Saint-Pierre are always PACKED, especially Chez Tonton (even on weekdays). Le Saint des Seins is also worth checking out, though that one only gets busy on weekends.

Rents are cheap, the climate is very good since the city is so far south. The only downside I can think of is the fact that it's so far inland. But there's lakes and shit you can do a day trip to in the summer.

Unfortunately, there's many blacks, but that can't be helped these days when it comes to France. It didn't seem as bad as other cities, though.

Pic related, a summer night along the Garonne

>>2402477
They have a fair amount of tourism, but it didn't strike me as an expat city in particular. Most of those types go off to Madrid, being the capital, or Barcelona. IIRC the houses are more affordable too. It still has some edgy shit like crappy 'ANTIFA ZONE' graffiti, but in reality most people are extremely chill. Never had any crime issues or felt unsafe. There's stuff open until very late in the night. Even very late I'd sometimes see families. It's a beautiful city, but much like the rest of Spain it very ugly modern civil architecture (France and Italy have their share too, but Spain is arguably dogshit when it comes to this). There's lots of smaller towns nearby which are cosy for a visit or possibly work out as a home too. Sagunto in particular. Albaraccin is one of the best places for bouldering in the world, and it is close by. The metro is cheap and covers pretty much covers most of the city. Maybe rent an Airbnb for a month and see how you find it? Then check out different suburbs, etc. I rented a small studio flat in the city center for 540 + bills, and split it with my ex. So we ended up paying each like 300€ per month.

The important thing - be wary of pickpockets on public transport. I witnessed with my very own eyes as a group of Gypsy women tried to pickpocket some Chinese woman. DESU I was clueless at that moment since earlier I spend a year in Asia, so I forgot those people (Gypsies) exist.

>>2403288
I am currently in an AirBnB. The problem is their prices are 2-4 times the normal rent price plus it's impossible to rent them in the long term due to already being booked at some point in the future or have already someone living there on day to day basis (correct me if I'm wrong, but in France, there is a law which prohibits renting Airbnb for longer than 120 days. Thus my 2 previous stays were in apartments normally occupied by the host or their family).

Regarding hotels, among the common brands, Ibis Styles seems to be the cheapest, which is still relatively expensive for the long term (ca. 80$ per night).

>>2403244
>The only problem I have it's extremely hard to rent an ordinary apartment without having a French job, bank and/or guarantor.
You can try Facebook groups for expats or apartments in the area. I've run into people willing to rent to me under the table this way. They save on taxes, so it's win-win.

It'll be an uphill battle though, because French landlords are jumpy about renting to those who aren't copacetic. This is because they have the most retarded squatting laws in the world. Niggers break into boomers' houses while they're on vacation. By the time they arrive, they've been around for a month, so they can't be evicted. The owner has to initiate a legal process that could last years to get his own property back.

Make sure your online presence isn't dodgy before you reach out to people looking for a place to stay. You'll end up paying for the low-trust environment one way or another, either by paying more or paying upfront. I don't think there's anything you can do about that, I'm afraid. Even on AirBnB, some boomer bitch cancelled my stay because I didn't have any reviews.

Whenever I visit my gf who lives in Cannes, I always liked going to Mougins. There’s nothing much apart from restaurants, parks and a nice village centre but it’s just nice to look at. The whole area is nice. There are some towns to avoid such as Vallauris because it’s full of immigrants but if you drive through you won’t notice much, as the ols buildings are still pretty to look at.

Honestly, what I love the most about the area is basically all the Pré-Alpes area right next to Cannes; it’s basically a mountainous zone but not crazy high with easy access. Villages like Andon, Saint Cesaire sur Siagne etc are just so nice.

Then if you go further up behind Nice, towards Mercantour, it’s another deal. It’s called the arrière-pays niçois and yeah, you get real mountains and you basically have alpine villages, but southern french/northern italian style. Very charming and extremely safe. Immigrants hate mountains.

posts.com:
I post this in every Vegas thread, but here goes,

For hiking, go to Red Rocks. Park at the Calico Basin parking area for free. Climb to the top. It's a crazy scramble up through crevices and over giant boulders.

Another awesome hike is the Arizona Hot Springs trail. You hike through a slot canyon. There are some awesome hot springs you can bath in. You can actually climb down all the way to the Colorado River.

For food, go to West Spring Mountain and eat in Chinatown. Hachi, Viet Noodle House, Ramen Sora, Ichiza are all amazing.

For gambling, I'd go downtown. The table limits are lower. You get more bang for your buck. Fremont Street at night is always fucking crazy fun for people watching. The best game in vegas is craps. Best odds and the most entertaining. Play the pass line and back up your bet with odds.

Weed is legal. Just buy your drugs at a legal weed store. Don't do business with drug dealers in vegas. You'll get murdered.

The Cirque shows are all pretty good. Ka is probably my favorite. One show is enough.

posts.com:
A few things I learnt from my trip:

Stock up on drinks and snacks at Walgreens or Target next to the MGM, don't buy any cans, bottles or snacks at a hotel.

Fremont Street and Circus Circus are both complete bitches to get to. Don't expect to walk to them or be able to get the monorail to them.

The buffets are terrible value for money now and half of them a "brunch" buffets which mean they're split between breakfast and lunch so the range suffers. Maybe do one for the novelty but just eat at regular restaurants for the rest, you'll get better food and you can still fill yourself up and have it come out cheaper.

If you're a light sleeper, either get some white noise generator or turn the fan on the AC up. Noisy drunk people and heavy doors that slam hard are a bitch.

Older and smaller strip hotels gaming floors either have eye watering levels of cigarette smoke or pump out huge amounts air freshener to counter it. If you're intending to use your hotel to game and can't deal with smoke, don't stay at one of the cheap "classic" strip hotels.

Comp drinks servers all but run past you in my experience. You have to be proactive or at least keep a look out to get drinks.

I ended up using the monorail far more than I was expecting. It's worth getting a multi-day ticket if you're at a hotel that has a station. There are various ways of getting discounts (MyVegas lets you exchange easy to get points for vouchers and the monorail vouchers are one of the better vouchers you can earn that isn't always out of stock).

Slots are low odds and low volatility (at least on the strip). Very unlikely they'll do anything other than slowly drain away your money.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2388898
Bluffing is a much smaller part of poker than you'd think. Call with OK hands, raise with good hands. You should be folding 75% of your hands at least. If you have a strong starting hand, don't limp. At lower limit tables the guy who raises first preflop (unless he gets re-raised) wins most hands

>>2395044
>Lowest possible volitility:
You play $1 and the reels come in $0.85 every single spin. Most of the money paid out by the slot goes on low wins

>Highest possible volitility:
Every 1,100,000 spins, it wins $1,000,000 and never wins outside of that. Most of the money paid up by the slot goes on high win

US slots are basically all low X bet wins. They may have $10,000 jackpots but they never pay out on low stakes and even if people play the max stakes of ~$4 you're still going to go an entire holiday never having seen anyone hit then (and a 2500x max win is considered low for a slot) . Most people will see a steady stream of < 10x wins and features that almost never go above 50x.

With low volitility, people play for a long time, but almost no one comes out with a profit. With high volilitility, people who don't win get their money drained quickly but a % of people leave the slots having had a massive win.

Outside observation: It was always a racist country. It was simply slightly less racist than its southern neighbor, the United States.

Canada’s historical mistreatment of its First Nations citizens is on display for the world to see. While the nation had reached some accommodations with the various tribes, it’s still very clear that the First Nations people are viewed as being second class citizens in many areas of Canada, particularly in areas with large populations of tribal members. The poor state of infrastructure on many of the reserves also clearly indicate that the government’s priority is not the residents of those areas.

As far as Blacks: While Canada was never as racist as the Deep South of the United States, segregation (de jure and de facto) were very common in Canada until the 1960s. Black Canadians who descended from either people brought over as slaves, former sea farers and escaped American slaves, lived in segregated areas, faced discrimination for jobs and financing and were often harassed by law enforcement and White Canadians. While this changed drastically in the last 50 years ( due in part to changes in the US and an influx of Afro-Carribbeans and African immigrants and refugees) , racism is not uncommon in areas of Canada which have small non-White populations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393549
Asians - Both East and South Asians have experienced a great deal of discrimination in Canada, although the fact that many came to Canada with wealth or were able to move into the middle and upper classes within a generation or so seems to have tempered this somewhat. Just as in the United States, most Asians and their descendants live in and around the major cities and urban areas, so the prejudice that they experience isn’t as widespread as the prejudice against Blacks and First Nations people seems to be. It does , however exists as referenced below.

Latinos - The recent influx of Latinos into the country seems to have provoked some prejudice against. However, Canada’s Latino population is relatively small, most confined to the cities, and it really hasn’t integrated into the mainstream. As climate change worsens and it becomes clear that Canada can support many more people than its harsh winters currently allows, there are likely to be more immigrations from Latino majority nations which are likely to face the need to flee that change. If history is any indicator if/when their numbers increase, so will the prejudice and discrimination that they face.

Canada is not a bad country, and its racism isn’t as profound as it is in many areas of the United States. It’s not “turning racist.” It IS racist, but it is also slightly less so than many other countries in the Western world.

I can tell you right now sri lanka is absolutely stunning, and an amazing place to visit. It has a very rich history, culture and beautiful landscapes.

It's also by far the cleanest country in South Asia.

Essentially the country has been coloninized three times by the Dutch, Portuguese and British. Each leaving behind their own piece of history.

Before that, in the 9th century, the country served as an Arab trade outpost/halfway point to South East Asia. There are still tons of Muslim architecture to see and the population is around 10% Muslim.

Even before that, there are thousands of years old fortresses such as The Lion Fortress of previous kingdoms.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
Dear /trv/eterans,

I have decided to create a thread for those interested in general information regarding living abroad. I think a lot of threads tend to discuss some singular aspects of living in certain countries, but I feel like regrouping these, no matter if they're country-specific or not, would be worth it, for the sake of archiving interesting information within one single (or a series of thread). This thread is aimed at prospecting beginners.

>Why should I live abroad ?
Many reasons. Cost of life can be better abroad, job opportunities more favorable to your field of work, a society you're more in tune with (safety, values). Other possibilities include doing an academic exchange or a double diploma, maybe an internship of some kind that will enhance your CV to prospective recruiters from your home country (or the one you want to go to.)

>But I don't want to live there forever !
It's fine, most people don't and leave after a few years. You don't have to marry a local, buy a house and stay there forever. Sometimes it's nice to go out there, take it out of your system, then come back all grown up and with some new tricks up your sleeve.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>What do you mean by that ? What do I gain from doing a temporary expatriation?
It really depends on how fruitful it was, but aside from whatever professional experience you've gain from it, by doing you so you have learned to leave your comfort zone, forced yourself into socializing with people who had no reason to talk to you besides speaking English and probably befriended some, negotiated for jobs and deals with people that are completely foreign to you and learned what it truly meant to be alone and be your own island, sometimes. If you came to say, Asia, with nothing more than a high school degree and nothing else but your hands, you've also learned how to network, find a job, and to pay your bills you actually had to learn how to keep that job. Of course, perhaps the conditions that made you get the job in the first place won't be there at home, which will make you stay. But at least you're actually functional now. And you'll be able to figure something out.

>Is immigration/expatriation something I should prepare ?
The more you prepare it, the better. Learning the local language (not necessarily bilingual but every bit helps), acquiring a skill, gathering information on how to get in and what visa schemes are available for you are all too important parts of a successful experience abroad.

>why the tripcode ?
Because I won't LARP. The answer you will receive from me will either be something I know to be true from personal experience. And the tripcode ensures that if I truly am bullshitting you, I can get called out for everything i've said throughout the series of threads that will be posted. It's a win-win.

And with that, the thread begins. If you're experienced, don't hesitate to share your experiences, tips and tricks you know. If you're not, don't hesitate to ask all the questions you want to ask.
P.S : human trafficking solliciters, remember that you're violating US law.

No problem. I'm only talking about Taiwan because that's what I know, and you seem to have either Taiwan or Japan as an endgoal. You won't solve being a shut-in by meeting up open people. You'll solve it by either meeting people who match your energy or truly learning why you can't socialize.

Introverts don't want to talk shop because they think small talk is a thing for retards, when really, small talk is the human way to show that they want to sniff your butt and enter your social circle so they can actually open up to you. Ironically, go really autistic and try to get into deep shit with them and they fucking freak out like anybody else because that's not what normally constituted people do, so damned if you do, and damned if you don't. Other things being invited to go have a meal with a group or with a friend and often refusing, which people understand as a rejection of friendship and not just a circumstantial thing, if repeated more than once.
It doesn't matter where you go, this is true everywhere.

>Are people open to be my friends ?
Since you said you were autistic, i'll tell you how it goes. In general, most people, Taiwanese included, are open to be your friend, provided you have some kind of pretext to meet them. If you don't know anybody, are not partaking in any hobbies and do not have a job yet, why would a perfect stranger befriend you ? Think about this problem, and trying to find some solutions on your own would be a good exercise.

Second, I always recommend people to go out and meet the expats in Taipei. They're a varied, decent bunch, very open, and are present in pretty much every night scene, they understand what it is to be a complete stranger to everyone and having to spontaneously meet new folks, and until you can understand how to make friends with locals, they can also introduce you to some. Internet people (not just 4chan) pretend they snob them but it's really that they've never talked to them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391118
>>2391118
People always say it's the best way but the way it happens makes it so that it basically never does. MNCs function in such a way that every national branch is its own company. They bill shit to each other, and either compete with, or work in fields that aren't quite the ones back home.

For example, a lot of MNCs will have folks working sales abroad to sell the products produced back home. And the people they will hire are obviously locals because they might be cheaper or just more at ease with communicating with the locals. Also, hiring an equivalent foreign worker is pound to pound as skilled as a local is considered bad practice and is starting to get heavily curbed in Asia.

Therefore, differentiation is key. Differentiation through diplomas (Prestigious ones), differentiation through specialization (PhDs in certain fields of expertise that are needed there, for example, or at least +5 year in a field but more is better).

If you're ballsy enough you can point out a certain need in a foreign branch, explain how to fill it so they can tailor a job offer for you there, too.
This being said, a lot of people manage to get to work abroad if they have +5 years exp in dev, sometimes less. Foreign internships, exchanges and double diplomas during your studies can help if you take the necessary steps professionally to make it work.

In a nutshell, anything that makes you a better person than a local works. And that also goes by evening the playing fields. Some countries have visa schemes that facilitate foreign hiring for skilled workers. Speaking the local language in a professional capacity also helps leveling the playing field and beating other foreign contenders. Again, you don't necessarily need to do all that to try your luck. But I suggest you orient yourself by tailoring yourself to be a competitive foreign worker as you go, which will only better your odds. Also, seriously, the field. Don't go to china with a pol sci degree.

Alternatively, just take some time there to look for ways to find a job.

Singapore allows you to look for a job on a tourist visa. Save up, and you can defintiely find a private room for around 1k a month, possibly cheaper in Singapore (I am looking at this semester's Airbnb offers to make sure), and all you really need is just one room, one bathroom, and enough place for your clothes (possibly two suits for job interviews), and an internet connection. You could possibly stay more to maximize your chances and enlarge the window of opportunities. Of course, don't just go there without any clue. Apply for job offers, make sure you mention that you will be available for an interview during said time period, and see what gives. No need to go for a month if you've only got one offer.
