I believe in the material, meat and potatoes. I am interested in the things that I know will bring me happiness. Call me a hedonist if you want, but I refuse to do things that will, further down the line, only bring me depression, contempt for other people, and spend my precious life on this earth.
If there is a more gratifying job, a better partner to be with, a better place to be in, i'll go right there and I see no reason to deprive myself of anything that could be a step up. An argument can be made about what makes it truly a step-up, sure, but it is undeniable that for some people in certain countries, you can really improve your life by going abroad. I actually believe that a temporary experience (which is what an expatriation is, by the way) is nice to have. Discovering foreign cultures in an in-depth way is a life-changing experience and it doesn't have to be a permanent one.

Also, just because you have less value in your country doesn't mean that this value is inherent to you. Maybe being an introverted engineer in a western country that has abandoned its industrial sector translates to being a polite, at ease socially engineer in Taiwan's booming industry ? Maybe being a French chef in France is hardly well paid and recognized because we've got so many of them, but it translates to being a great chef abroad with very interesting and classy recipes ?
In other words, why should an Eskimo who failed at selling popsicles in Alaska be called a failure because he decided to try his luck in Malaysia where the weather's too fucking hot all year around ?
People who think like this are so deep in sunk cost fallacy they can see the Mariana Trench from there. "Look at my works ye mighty and despair" he fucking says, on top of his 9-5 mediocre job in a mediocre ass city not thinking he'll die and be forgotten like all the others. Being a loser is the human condition.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395192
>I thought increasingly in asia you require a degree level in whatever to qualify for English teaching at least I thought that was the case in China and Japan.
That is increasingly, and indeed, nearly always the case, and not just in China and Japan. Thailand requires degrees too, has done for years now.

People without degrees but with certifications can still sometimes find work in Thailand, typically either as private tutors or at the sleaziest of private language school sweatshops, but they can’t get work permits or non-immigrant visa sponsorship. So the work (and as often as not, the teachers’ residence) is under the table and officially illegal, with all the risk that implies. It’s been a few years since the last crackdown, but Thai authorities have caught and mass deported English teachers working without proper papers several times that I can remember.

The only place I’ve ever personally known someone to work full-time as a teacher without a degree was Cambodia, but there may be other Wild West possibilities out there.

Still almost certain to run into visa/permit problems, though.

posts.com: how do you find a job abroad? im a young engineer and id like to work in asia for a few years, im a bit clueless on how to find a job postings. i just tried linked in and some googling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395792
Linkedin, indeed. Check on the internet where do people post their job postings for a particular country. Get yourself some letters of recommendation. References are also ok but since some employers might not care since they can't really believe them, having some letters right off the bat can be a plus for these cases.
Possibly translate your CV.

If a country seriously strikes your fancy, you could try to go there for a week or two with the sole goal of networking. Meet literally anyone with the largest common denominator, aka alumnis, then dudes in your field you might meet in expat bars that are from your home country, and just ask around for pointers and tips (never directly for a job). Also, read up on this process of networking so you don't sound like a scummy hustler.


Add a lot of recruiters on linkedin from the particular country in the companies that interest you.

If you can arrange some interviews before your trip do so and make sure you specify the time period at which you will be present.

Finally, one of the bigger reason people struggle is because they either do not have enough experience , or they're not specialists in a field the local job market is interested in.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>>2395891
No one ever said it to be easy. It's hard and it requires foresight and preparation. Even the MNC route isn't granted.
But it happens. People every year manage to succeed in doing that, and fortune usually favors the bold. If all you do is sit down in the comfort of your home and job and apply for job postings abroad with a foreign address, unwilling to do your interviews physically, with little to no investment in staying by forcing into others the fact that you speak english and the unwillingness of doing nothing else, there is literally no reason why they should hire you.
Not only sponsoring a visa can be a pain in the ass to the HR, you going there and realizing you didn't like the place and leaving after a year makes it so not worth it for them to even consider you.

You should also compensate for the difficulty of the endeavor with a good enough volume. If you're looking to go to Taiwan, do them all-Taiwan, Japan, Korea, China, HK and Singapore. Even the ones you don't want -who cares ? My friend who was in a situation similar to yours, applied to around 500 offers over the course of a year and got around 5 interviews, 2 of which resulted in a "yes".

Another had literally no fucking experience whatsoever but just happened to save some money and went on a 2 month trip in Taiwan after college to celebrate. My man had a job lined up by the end of the first month. That guy was smart however, had the great idea of hiring a professional translator to rigorously translate his CV and cover letter, and the guy just played up to the HRs.

As for me, the reason why i'm here is because i've literally tailored my studies to finding a job there.Double diplomas, internships... There's a lot of things you can do to get yourself wherever you want provided you think about it soon enough.

Ironically, the best country you could move to to buy a home would be your own country, for legal reasons. The next best thing is Western Europe for the same reasons.

I think the Côte de Provence would be a great place. It is very quiet, very sunny, lots of trails and hiking, beaches and palm trees all over the coast. There's a good reason why so many americans buy property there. Other areas would include the Andalucian coast in Spain, too. If you're ballsy enough, you could try Morocco I guess. Places like this could get you a relatively nice house between 300 and 200k and a really good one at 500k, maybe get a small car for easy commuting and that's it, you're set for life, maybe get a TEFL cert and here you go.

Just make sure you live in the suburbs. avoid the big cities such as Marseille, Montpellier and Nice. You want nice and tranquil and safe, the suburbs of the mediterranean coast will be perfect for you.

Also, don't listen to the people who'll say the contrary. They're probably French and they suck at comparing since they have no experience of anything else.

>>2406560
If you are coming late-March or early April then you might have a chance to see the cherry blossoms bloom or at least some of the flowers. You can create the K-ETA and add any number but when you do the reservations then you can always update the K-ETA with the new number and address. It is fairly easy to change the information once you been approved. If you do not do the E-KTA then you'll have to fill out an arrival card. There is also a covid questionnaire you can write down or do it at a Korean website to get a QR code. Everything can be done the day you arrive but if you want to get in quickly then you can do it before hand.
Well surprisingly there is not many k-pop blasted at you as it would be in other countries. Usually Seoul has a more urban hiphop young culture that usually gets put under k-pop just for the reason that they used the Korean language. Hongdae would be the best play to be for music these days. There is many different kinds of cafes, restaurants, stores, and bars. There is also many clubs & they get filled since the Itaewon accident. There is a good location in Seoul that not many tourist go for several reasons. It is a new location that has a mix of modern and old aesthetics. It is a section in Seoul that has old steel mills and between them is a random cafe. It is best to go there as the sun goes down because it gives you a really nice feeling. It is located by the mall called Times Square.15 Yeongjung-ro, Yeongdeungpo-gu, Seoul. Many tourist avoid that area b/c that is the famous Red Light in Seoul. You can visit the red neon lights of that area if you are curious but mostly only cater to koreans. Anyways in that area you'll find the place I am telling you about. This is a random address to a bakery; you can explore this area and this would be were most of the places are. 15 Gyeongin-ro 79-gil, Mullae-dong, Yeongdeungpo-gu, Seoul

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2403998
Nice, I visit Chiang Mai and Chiang Rai all the time! Most anons only know about Pattaya and the other touristy places, so I'm glad you'll be taking some time to explore the humble yet wild north. Some things I've done up there that I can recommend:
> Visit the mountains. Doi Inthanon is the highest, but I can vouch for Doi Sa Ngo. I had a good picture of the sunrise I saw there but I can't find it now. Anyways, mountain camping is also pretty popular in Thailand nowadays, though it's more of a wintertime activity.
> Ride an elephant or (more ethically) visit an elephant sactuary. I've done both, these animals are truly beautiful and they're far more intelligent than the average Thai man/farang coomer.
> Attend a Buddhist ceremony. Most monks will allow you inside their temples, and you can take pictures so long as you remain respectful. I personally would avoid any invitations to attend a sutra chanting though, they're very boring.
> Go shopping at a night market. Chiang Mai is locally famous for its night market, just like how Bangkok is famous for its floating markets. Most of the vendors sell foodstuffs but you can also buy some cool souvenirs without the ripoff prices you'll find in Bangkok. If you don't know what to eat, just follow the long lines and point at menus.
> Hike with the hill tribes. The most famous is the Karen Long Neck. I did this when I was little so I don't remember much, but there's no better way to explore the Zomia. You can read about it if you want, it's "a land without governance". The Moken are also pretty cool and are enjoying their own form of political liberation, but they're in southern Thailand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2405114
(2/2)
Other than those activities, a lot of Thailand's appeal is food-related. I've attached the table of contents from Pok Pok by Andy Ricker, he goes over the best northern Thai dishes and you can use this to guide your culinary journey. Try to find pictures by googling if you can, if you can't I'll see what I can do. Also, if you're an adventurous eater, you can experience the pleasure and displeasure of trying the many unique proteins of the region (love me some snake, hate wasp larvae). Chiang Mai also has a booming coffee scene, some of the cafes are really stylish despite the north still being pretty rural.
Personally, whenever I visit Thailand (usually once yearly in the winter), I like to chill and do redneck things like fish in the rice paddies or go on motorbike/pickup truck joy rides. And honestly, even though those sound pretty boring in writing, it really captures the spirit of Thailand as a whole. It's an easygoing country.
Sorry, one more thing. There are definitely some things I would buy in Thailand to take back home, such as stuff that's just plain cheaper (Korean cosmetics, knockoff Chinese stuff that's 99% as good as the actual deal) and some unique things like retort curry pouches and special spices. Thai cooking is really spice-dependent, but that's the only real barrier. Once you can source your galangal/lemongrass/whatever you can replicate the food you had in Thailand back at home, and that helps keep the memories alive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Depends on the weather. If it's nice and sunny, take the ferry across to Angel Island and rent some bikes and do the loop. The views are amazing and the bike trail is awesome.

The Musée Mécanique at Fisherman's Wharf is good, but don't eat around there.

The Sutro Baths are cool.

If you want to do a cool waterfall hike, go check out Cataract Falls. It's a tough uphill hike, but a really gorgeous forest with giant redwood trees and a lake.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: if youre gonna actually be in San Jose/south to east bay: mission peak is a nice hike where you can see a pretty view of the bay at the top. coyote hills has a nice overlook of the water but it might be a little stinky. downtown SJ is super nostalgic to me and has an art museum. banana leaf in fremont is a good malaysian place.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2405023
go to the santa cruz beach boardwalk.
spend an afternoon walking down the embarcadero in sf. start at the ferry plaza building visiting the market inside.
visit cannery row and monterey.
considering napa is near by, try local wine if you're into that. there's also some amazing breweries - fieldwork being one of the best.
asian and indian food is amazing in the bay, but it's probably just as good in ny.

if you're staying in san jose - check out san pedro market for dinner. south 1st street also has some nice places to eat. get a burrito from la victoria or iguanas and always ask for extra orange sauce. camino and happas are the best breweries imo.

oh and in & out burger just to say you've been.

these are all basic recommendations from a local. a bit touristy, but being that your only staying for a week i'd say this would give a good experience at the very least.

posts.com:
>>2402723
Yes, it is. You can anchor by a beach and save on docking. That said, from time to time you'll have to go to a marina to do some maintenance.
You learn to sail in easy conditions in 1-3 months, 6 months you learn a good deal of sailing and I think one year is enough to travel long distance (ocean crossing), although it would be better to have a more knowledgeable person as captain. There are people who just take classes for one month, start sailing along the coast of their countries for a few months and then cross the atlantic. So it is doable in less time.
Boats are expensive but living costs are actually cheap if you're doing most repairs, sailing in your own and not docking in expensive marinas.
That said, would you really enjoy it? It's slow, a bit dangerous, can get tedious if you're not used to be lonely, it's easy to get mad at people (if you're not sailing alone)... Also, if you plan to visit cities you will have to dock at marinas (so the price goes up).
Also keep in mind that boats are really small. In bad weather you would have to face the elements or stay confined in the small salon. If sailing alone you would have to sleep for small periods of time as you must keep an eye in the route, fishing nets and boats along your way.
My 0.20 cents: crossing the atlantic must be a nice thing to do once. Sailing by the coast of onefew countries for a month also is fun. But too much time in a boat is tiresome. And I say this as a loner by heart.

next month I'm traveling to Iraq, looking to spend a few days exploring Baghdad and some normie-tier ruins (AKA Babylon).

If it's like a shard of pottery or some coins I might just stick it in my wallet with my otherwise normal coins to blend in through the x-ray. >>2404226
I've only been to Lanzarote but I absolutely loved it. Beautiful beaches, but the interior is even cooler. Parque Nacional de Timanfaya is cool as shit and absolutely worth, basically there was a giant eruption in the 1700s that buried multiple villages and covered the entire interior of the island with lava. Very very cool. Lots of art by a guy named Cesar Manrique, really cool houses and a cactus park. Unique wine region as the volcanic soil has special properties, very much worth visiting a winery and seeing how they do it - basically they grow grapes with a wall of pumice stone behind them which siphon the moisture out of the wind, since it's so dry there. The entire island is basically a giant desert covered in lava.

All that to say it's very cool, one of the most unique places I've ever been, kinda like a Spanish Hawaii. I haven't been to any of the other islands so can't compare but I would absolutely go back to las Canarias to see how they compare to Lanzarote. It's a very unique place with a lot of cool cultural stuff and history. Honestly could be its own country, it's that different from the mainland.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I recently spent 3 weeks in Iraq, both north and south. Some pertinent info and thoughts if you're looking to do the same.

Entry + visa - I entered Iraq through the land border with Kuwait which you, if you know about Kuwait, will not be surprised to learn was a fucking hassle. Internet says there's a public bus that runs to the border but there isn't, the only option is a taxi. I got to the border and learnt that I needed a green piece of paper from the ministry of interior authorising me to leave Kuwait to Iraq via land, and that I could only get it from the office back in the city. This wasted an entire day, as the office was closed by the time I got back to the city. I got it the next morning from the interior office next to the airport - it only took 5 minutes and didn't cost anything. Back at the border, crossing is fairly straight forward. The Iraqi side is underdeveloped and pretty dusty. Visa on arrival for all the good western passports is available at all ports of entry and cost me $77USD, and was issued surprisingly quickly. From the border town of Safwan, you'll probably take a cab to Basra. I went straight to Baghdad from the Basra taxi station, about a 6 hour drive. I imagine flying into Baghdad is far more straightforward.

Baghdad - a surprisingly nice city compared to what you may think. Much nicer than Cairo, I thought, and enough to keep you busy for up to a week, although 4 days would be fine. My favourite thing to do was strolling through Mutannabi street and the adjacent areas where the local craftsmen, book sellers, and antique dealers are. The mosques around this area are stunning and will give you a good sense of the distinct architectural style of Baghdad, i.e. intricate brickwork and blue and yellow domes. If you like modern stuff like malls, chic cafes etc then Mansour area is very nice. Museums, monuments, mosques (go to kadhimiya) and food are plentiful and will keep you busy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402967
Liquor shops are present and openly advertised. Women dress anywhere from jeans and tees to the full burqa. Careem works everywhere in Baghdad and is very convenient, as navigating the local minivans would be practically impossible without being a local. Traffic is standard developing-world-tier, frustrating but inevitable. Airbnbs are basically non-existent everywhere in Iraq and so I ended up staying in budget hotels. In Baghdad, the cheap ones (~25USD per night) can be found in the bataween area. Quality tends to be pretty shit, but if you just want a bed, it's fine. I stayed in Hotel Diwan. Baghdad feels safe enough and not tense, but keep your head on a swivel anyway. Standard precautions, don't walk late at night, dress conspicuously, speak a bit of arabic.

Karbala and Najaf - the two holjest Shia sites in Iraq, along with kadhimiya in Baghdad and Askari in Samarra. Both fairly well developed (relative to the region) due to the number of pilgrims. Go to either one first depending on your itinerary, and get there from the Al alawi south garage in Baghdad. You can take a bus or shared taxi, and the same for the next city. Hotel situation is much the same as above. 1-2 full days in each is appropriate, because all there really is to see are the shrines. Great places to learn about shia Islam and meet people from all over the world. People tend to be friendly here and strike up conversation, ask where you're from etc. No issue saying that you're not Muslim, just follow the customs that will be very evident and displayed on the entrances to the shrines. Shrines are open 24/7 and you can even sleep in them if you're so inclined.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402967
People tend to be quite fair in Iraq and I didn't really experience anyone trying to charge me the standard yt prices, though this could be because lots of people assumed I'm Lebanese or because I can speak enough rubbish arabic to make any given vendor smile. The average Iraqi is very happy to welcome guests, though, and I had people offer to pay for my meals on several occasions when they learnt I was foreign.

Babylon - a day trip from karbala. Most disappointing thing I visited in Iraq desu. Site was all but abandoned apart from one guard sitting on a plastic chair, and the entrance fee for foreigners is 25k dinars (~18USD), which is absurd for Iraq. Just a bunch of brick walls with no explanatory signage or context. Might as well have been waking in any given field. The blue gate is cool I suppose but isn't the original one, that's in Berlin. Worth going, though, to visit Saddam's palace that's on the hill overlooking the city.

Samarra - 2 hour shared taxi from Baghdad, Al alawi north garage. Samarra isn't controlled by the fed gov and is instead run by a Shia militia called the peace companies. You'll get stopped at the checkpoint before the entrance to the city and made to hand over your passport to them. Your shared taxi, presumably filled with locals, will be told to continue and you'll be kept at the checkpoint where they'll call some local driver and assign him to you for the day. Westerners aren't allowed to stay overnight in Samarra, and apparently the security situation is still quite tenuous there. It's a shithole anyway, the only two things to see are malwiya mosque, the big spiral minaret, and Askari shrine. Your assigned driver probably knows you're there to see them anyway and will take you there and back to the checkpoint where you'll collect your passport. Malwiya is cool, but again is 25k for yt. Askari is free, and worth seeing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402967
Mosul - one of the most surreal places I've ever seen. 5hr shared taxi from Baghdad north, again, or you could continue on from samarra I guess. There isn't a whole lot going on in mosul in the normal sense, but walking around the rubble of the old city is unreal, as is meeting locals and hearing their stories about life under Isis. See if you can co-ordinate permissions with UNESCO to visit Al Nuri mosque which is being reconstructed, as well as the church of the lady of the hour. I asked around at some of the other destroyed churches, and the construction guys were nice enough to let me in and wonder around. I stayed in hotel Al safer on the west side, which was very basic (squat toilet) but fine for 25k per night. The city feels quite sad, but the security presence is heavy and it's safe. Locals are happy to meet visitors and I got invited to the house of a guy who I met wondering around the destroyed areas. He told me stories of his relatives being killed by Isis and how his house was blown up. Definitely worth going, if you're interested in the recent history of Iraq.

Kurdistan - I was sick for most of the time I was here, unfortunately, but a bit of info. Your federal Iraq visa works to enter here, but not vice versa. Erbil is just ok. Very relaxed, safe, and relatively liberal. The citadel and surrounding bazaar is nice, but there's really not much else to do in the city. Duhok is much nicer, I thought, and allows for interesting day trips. I went to Lalish, the yazidi holy city, and it was fascinating. You can't wear shoes in the whole village, and the architecture is very distinct. They have these conical spires which supposedly absorb the sun, and the whole area is very pretty and mountainous. Can't say much else for Kurdistan unfortunately, due to illness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Money - my Australian card worked in quite a few of the ATMs in Iraq. Some charged fees, some didn't. ATMs are surprisingly scarce though, particularly outside of Baghdad, so if you go to Mosul and Kurdistan, make sure you have sufficient cash. There are also shops that look like Forex places that can act as ATMs, they charge you with an EFTPOS machine and then give you cash. I had mixed success with my card working at these places, though.

Food - typical arab fare, which is to say pretty good. Meat, bread, pickles, hummus, falafel etc. Iraqi shish kebabs are the best I've had anywhere in the world. Shawarma places and other local fast food is ubiquitous on every corner. Try the classic Iraqi roast fish called masgoof. There are also street carts selling boiled chickpeas called 'leblebi' and boiled beets which are a great snack. Karbala and Najaf are also famous for their coconut oil sweets called daheen, which are sickly.

I think that's it for now. Definitely recommend a visit.

Oh, and basra. I flew to Basra from Erbil for the final of the gulf Arab cup football. Got caught in a crowd crush where a dozen people ended up dying because ppl without tickets stormed the gates. Had to bribe my way into the stadium even though I had a ticket. People hanging off the railing and stuff, three to a seat, had a guy literally sitting on my shoulders with his legs dangling. Probably 110k in a 65k capacity stadium. Clearly uncomfortable, but a mental experience that you couldn't really get in many other places, and Iraq ended up winning in an insanely dramatic match, so it was worth it. Basra itself has some interesting stuff by the water, like Saddam's old yacht that's sinking. Didn't stay for too long otherwise though, so can't recommend much else there.

It's like Uber. The market catches up to these things and it stops being a side hustle for regular, honest people and becomes a primary income for a dedicated cabal of opportunistic grifters. People are going back to hotels because of this and also because hotels are fighting back. They became more consumer friendly, dropped their prices, improved their rewards programs, fixed things like the always malfunctioning machines and shitty internet, and generally moved away from the "fuck you, already got your money" mentality.
The last 2 Airbnbs I stayed at had mice in them (and they were rated very well too). I've never had anything like that at a hotel. I'm not paying increasingly expensive prices to get that kind of shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2400965
if you want to stay longer than 3 months in one stay you need a residence permit. To get a residence permit you need an local address, EU passport, proof of funds/income, and european healthcare card. You fill out some paperwork, make a picture, and then you get and residence permit id card. It will cost you less than 100 euro and is done in a week. Though would be easier if you get an local lawyer to help you deal with the immigration office and paper work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2406030
just think about it seriously
set a time limit in your head "i'm gonna analyze my negative thoughts for 30s"
find out the cause of those thoughts. For example, if you had less than stellar experiences with people, see if the cause was external or internal. Or if you failed an interview, maybe you didn't give enough effort in the days leading up to that interview.
Everything have a cause. The shitty part is that seemingly trivial events can have a hold on you for a very long time. That's why we have laws punishing those causing emotional and psychological damages
but the most important thing is to not overthink and shit on yourself. The world doesn't give a fuck if you suffer alone, so kick those thoughts in the balls and man up

I am subscribed to quite a lot of quality channels. Some well known travel vloggers and some touristy/theme park/coaster channels that deserve more subscribers. Here's a list of the ones i watch the most:
Obvious channels/100k+ subscribers:
>Backpacker Ben
https://youtube.com/@BackpackerBen
Brit who has done videos with Bald but is way more likeable and relatable to the average traveler
>Dale Philip
https://youtube.com/@Dale_Philip
One of the more tolerable food guys
>Kurt Caz
https://youtube.com/@KurtCaz
Puts himself in some seriously fucked up places and situations, consistently A+ content
>Super Enthused
https://youtube.com/@SuperEnthused
One of the only bearable theme park vloggers with a lot of subscribers. I mostly only watch her non-disney uploads.
Grimmlifecollective:
https://youtube.com/@grimmlifecollective
Goth freaks but interesting vids & niche movie-related sights
Hidden gem channels:
>My Expat Diary:
https://youtube.com/@MyExpatDiary
German vlogger who comes off as genuine/authentic and has honest opinions
>Kyde & Eric
https://youtube.com/@kydeanderic
US expats living in Japan. Have 700+ vlogs covering most of the country. Can sometimes be annoying but not too bad.
>Near From Home
https://youtube.com/@NearFromHome
Best Germany channel
>Jacob the Carpetbagger
https://youtube.com/@TheCarpetbagger
Best US roadside attractions channel on YouTube. Can be obnoxious but you get used to it after a few videos.
Nobodies but showing promise:
>Obscurist Tourist
https://youtube.com/@ObscuristTourist
US vlogger/roadside tourism
>Ray Out There
https://youtube.com/@RayOutThere
boring personality but decent roadside vlogs
>Roadside Explorers
https://youtube.com/@RoadsideExplorers
Their vlogs arent that well shot but their content is curated very well for kitsch culture/Americana. Great docs of defunct shit from around the US.

I've been on that exact ship twice.

Cruises are by far the best way to do a vacation.
Pay a set price, about $1,000pp/pw often less.
That's it. It's all included. Drinks, food, alcohol, entertainment. It's all there and included.
You get to relax, eat some of the best food you will ever fucking have, and visit a new country every day.

The ships themselves are something else.
The Oasis class, which Wonder is part of, has literal fucking parks inside them.

I've been on 6 cruises total, and always had a good time.

If you ever wanted to go on one, do it.

Just don't cheap out and go with some jew cruise line.

Royal Caribbean, NCL, and Virgin are the best for the average person.
Celebrity, Viking, and Princess are nice but high-end. Like, you need to dress nice high-end.
Disney if you have kids.
Fuck any other cruise line. Especially Carnival.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. Do whatever you can to stay at places that at least have a minifridge, it just makes everything much easier

2. Getting enough protein will be the main challenge, since most meat needs to be cooked and/or refrigerated. If you have a fridge you can buy ham or other deli meat that doesn't need to be cooked. Outside the US you can find unrefrigerated eggs that you can keep at room temp and slonk raw if you have too, but I think almost all eggs sold in the US are refrigerated and have to be kept that way.

3. If you're traveling by car there's no reason you can't take an induction cooker and skillet, or instapot with you which really expands your cooking options.

I think minimizing eating out is wise, but the other side of the equation is finding things that are healthy. I eat a lot of Chipotle. Heavy in sodium but otherwise I would say it's a fresh and healthy meal. Mediterranean food too is good. Non processed stuff is pretty hip these days so it's not too hard to find even in cow towns. Sandwiches are good too. You could make those in the hotel or find a deli. Subway maybe isn't the best but still decent I would say.

Good luck with life on the road.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2405126
Mostly this.

I personally found the planning part insanely hard. What saved me were eg. sweet potatoes, bananas, that type of stuff. Even when I was unprepared, cause it was a last minute trip, I just bought a sweet potato per day, or some carrots, tossed them in the microwave until they became soft. I don't care what excuses people say to defend fast food and most of the restaurant food, they mostly just make me feel worn down. But just give me a nice sweet potato, and that keeps me running for half a day. (It can be garnished almost like bread, too, if someone gets bored of it.)

Good, home-cooked style restaurants and delis and streetfood stalls exist, so if you have the time and energy, do seek them out. But they are extremely rare.

What else... I sometimes make an insane amount of veggie cream soup and bone broth. I freeze most of it in small batches. It's not practical on the road at all, but like every time I get home I inevitably am just too tired to do much in the kitchen. But like tossing a block of frozen soup in a bowl and microwaving it... That's doable, and extremely yummy.

It's alright to get into a pattern of just eating out when you are tired or had no time to plan. But get back to cooked meals when you can.

Also gym or just a 10 min walk daily... Remember to not just stare at Netflix right after work, create some work-to-personal-time translation routine for the hotel days.

After a ten minute walk in Aswan, I returned to my hotel and rested in the lobby. Taxi drivers then WALKED INTO THE LOBBY to try and get my service. I had to retreat to my room.

The guide will threaten the policeman with a friend he has at the station to knock it off. So consider the group tour an insurance against the police screwing you over - and bear in mind, no matter how bad the police/army treat you, they are treating you with eggshells in comparison to how they treat the locals.

I spent a couple weeks in Egypt in 2019. It wasn’t nearly as bad as people on /trv/ and Reddit made it sound. I had to deal with some obnoxious camel touts around the pyramids. Aside from that, nobody really bothered me. If you can speak about 10 words in Arabic and aren’t the sort of person who’s going to have a long-winded, desperate conversation with everyone who approaches you, it’s not difficult to avoid most of the so-called harassment. This is especially true if you have absolutely any experience travelling in other developed countries.

I grew up in the U.S. but lived in India for several years. Have also lived in Istanbul and Bogota. Egypt isn’t anything extraordinary in terms of hassle. You’ll have people bother you around major sites of touristic interest, but most of them will piss off if you don’t look or act like an absolute chump. I say that as someone who’s as White as a bed sheet and looks nothing like the average Egyptian.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2405950
Cont.

The only important piece of advice, aside from learning very basic directional commands in Arabic, is to buy a local SIM and exclusively use Uber. Egyptian taxi drivers are uniformly awful. If you’re not fluent in Arabic, they will never, ever agree to go by the meter or offer anything even resembling a fair price. I did have one Uber driver go around and around in circles for no reason, but Uber support refunded me for the trip after a 30-second chat conversation.

However, I visited as a solo male traveler. I would assume it would be much worse if you’re a woman, or travelling with a woman. Egyptian men can be next-level creepy: for everything people say about Indians, I’ve found that men will usually keep their distance if there’s another guy nearby (I’m married and also had my family visit me there a few times). It’s the same in Turkey—Turkish guys can be fucking weird, too, but they’ll typically view women who appear to be in any sort of relationship as off-limits, and will never say or do anything to a woman who’s with another man.

I got the distinct impression that Egyptians just don’t give a fuck, and will—as several YouTube videos have shown—jizz themselves over any particularly feminine pair of ankles.

If you care fuck all about ancient history, then probably not. If you do, there are lots of other ancient megaliths as equally impressive as the pyramids. Temples of Karnak, Hatshepsut, underground tombs in Luxor, Abu Simbel. And even I, a complete dumbass, could appreciate the museums.
On actual fun hoodrat shit, there plenty of spots to scuba dive in the red sea. It's really beautiful and warm even in the winter, and they don't care if you aren't certified. You can rent a quad for pretty much nothing and rip it across the desert in Hurghada. Or rent a scooter and ride it all over the country.
Yes Egypt and especially Cairo is a shithole, and you will be harassed constantly, but I actually really liked the shittiness and chaos of it. Wish I had spent more time there.

>>2396394
I lived in Saigon for years. It's easy to get a job teaching but you have to have a teaching certificate and work permit. Be careful of shitty schools, make sure to ask around before you sign any binding contracts. The traffic is a lot worse now than it was a decade ago because there are cars everywhere and the roads aren't designed for it.
I consider it my second home and will love it until the day I die, but it takes a while to grow on you. It reveals its beauty over the course of months and years. It also has an immense amount of poverty, corruption, suffering, and like any big city it will swallow you and spit you out. The party culture has a dark side.
>>2396396
a lot of people say Hanoi is the New York and Saigon is the LA, Hanoi is cultural capital and Saigon is the business capital, and I think there's some truth to that.

Check out some of the facebook groups and ask around. Maybe save enough money to travel through VN for a month and stay in Saigon and Hanoi for a week or two before committing to a place.

The ESL market is glutted nowadays so it's a bit harder to find jobs in the big cities especially but you'll still be able to find something, especially during the summer when language centers are looking. During the school year it's common to teach during the day at a public school and nights/weekends at a language center.

I miss Vietnam.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386906
Rural Colombia is indeed gorgeous in many spots, and Costa Rica has some of the most beautiful concentrated nature I’ve ever seen anywhere, while being safer and easier to get around (although Colombia is mostly safer than its reputation nowadays too). Urban Colombia, however, despite a bit of grit and risk in some spots, is far more charming than urban Costa Rica—San Jose, through which you will have to pass, is an ugly shithole, and while nearly every other town in the country is somewhat more attractive they’re small and have limited historical or cultural interest, apart from Cartago, which has an OK little colonial center.

All that said, the food isn’t particularly good in either country IMO. There are a few local specialties that are worth eating once or twice, but I would say that both Colombian and Costa Rican cooking tend toward the heavy, greasy, and bland.

Mexico or especially Thailand are both far better places to eat as far as I’m concerned. I don’t know Puerto Vallarta specifically, but Mexican beaches I have visited in the Yucatán and Riviera Maya can be very nice if a bit resort/package tourism dominated.

I know Thailand very well—lived there for years—and will always love the place, but I encourage most people to go somewhere other than Bangkok first and see BKK on the way out. I love the place in a lot of ways but love almost everywhere else in the country more. It’s hot, smoggy, has miserable traffic, and isn’t especially attractive, so it can make a bad first impression, but it undeniably has a great deal going on. There are as many favorite beaches there as there are people, but I’ve had great times on Ko Samui (easy mode, avoid Chaweng Beach, which is sleazy and grubby); Phuket (even easier mode, avoid Patong Beach, which is sleazy and grubby and Russian Mafia, I like the southern tip of the island); Ko Chang (no airport so takes a bit longer to reach, mix of hippies and smaller resorts); and others.

>>2389185
The best way is to just not do it. Tell your GP before you go on the trip that you're going on a trip, and you need your prescription for the entire duration of the trip. Add one month or something (depends on the lenght of your trip) to make sure that even if you get delayed for whatever reason you're not left without your presciption.
There are ofc variables, like the majority of the world has cheaper meds than the USA. And also some meds are extremely illegal in some countries, so look it all up. Based on the main ingredient, not the brand name.
In some third world countries your solution might work great, and you might get what you need, for cheaper, too. But let's say you go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to. The only reason to bring your home prescription is in case customs wants to check why you have certain meds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389484
I actually agree with all of your advice here, but
> go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to.

Isn’t necessarily true in my experience. A lot of European cities have walk-in travel clinics for foreigners that can sometimes fill prescriptions for visitors based on a foreign script, with relatively few questions asked. My wife accidentally ran out of thyroid meds while on holiday in Portugal once and was able to get what she needed from a clinic just by showing them the empty box with her name on the prescription label. And when I moved countries, I was able to get an armload of prescriptions from my new GP just by telling him the medications I needed (I have multiple chronic health conditions). That last case is different, of course, because it was implicit that I would have some kind of ongoing relationship with the doctor and he would eventually see blood work for me.

But assuming the medications involved aren’t dangerous or tightly controlled (probably wouldn’t work for anything psychoactive, definitely wouldn’t work for narcotics), it is often possible to get an emergency script from a foreign doctor in the west.

Still agree that the best option is to get a “vacation fill” of whatever you’re on to last as long as you will be away whenever possible, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I hate flying, going to be flying in a month from california to london, what's a drug that's guaranteed to knock me out cold the whole time? I'm awake at night a month ahead thinking about this flight, it's driving me crazy with anxiety. I want to try a few different medications before i go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391230
Ambien or another high-test hypnotic sleeping pill might do the trick. If you’re not concerned about potential abuse and addiction, you might also talk to a doctor about a small quantity of an anxiolytic like Xanax or Ativan, but any drug in the barbiturate or benzodiazepine families is more serious business than people like to think, and shouldn’t be used too casually. They’re all physically habit-forming with nasty withdrawal symptoms, and some people get unpleasant benzo hangovers that can leave you groggy and stupid for an extended period. They can, however, ameliorate anxiety symptoms very effectively in the short term, even if they don’t necessarily render you unconscious.

You should also think about jet lag—I agree with those experts who say that you should avoid trying to sleep at times when you wouldn’t be asleep at your destination while in transit. But it’s virtually impossible to do this perfectly, so if you need to conk out to survive a flight it’s not the end of the world even if it’s suboptimal.

If they haven’t already by the time I finish typing this, someone will surely suggest combining alcohol with one or more of the above. It might work, but I think it’s à fundamentally dumb idea—while alcohol can be good for making you pass out, it’s terrible for sleep quality, so it will make you less likely to stay asleep, and you’re likely to wake up unrested with a hangover in the middle of your flight.

I recommend looking up some anti-anxiety breathing exercises and guided meditation—it may sound like bullshit but in my experience as an anxious person it can also actually work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
Oh, and if you do end up going with a sleeping pill like Ambien or Lunesta, try it at home a few days before you fly to see how long it lasts in your case, so you can time your dosing appropriately. You will not enjoy dragging your ass through customs and immigration while still deeply under the influence of one of these drugs, nor do you want to still be comatose when you land.

Another psychoactive medication you might want to discuss with your doctor is trazodone; it’s an ancient antidepressant, but it also has some anti-anxiety and sedative properties and used to get prescribed for insomnia. I use a small dose daily at bedtime as part of a depression and anxiety regimen, and while I can’t say it knocks me out for ten hours, it does make me sleepy and I wake up more relaxed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391732
>Any tips on motion sickness pills? Never had them
Many of the OTC ones are based on dimenhydrinate; seems to work OK for my kids. Can make you a bit sleepy but not enough to be used as a sedative. It’s a dissociative/quasi-hallucinogen in the case of massive overdose or deliberate abuse by bored teenagers. Don’t drink alcohol while taking it, less for side effects and more because it seems to stop it from working almost completely.

You can also get scopolamine pills or patches, although these may be script-only depending on where you live; my uncle, who liked deep sea fishing but could also barf walking through a puddle, depended on these.

Another Rx-only drug that in my limited experience might be the most powerful is Ondansetron, AKA Zofran, which can even keep chemotherapy patients from upchucking. My wife got it once in the ER when she had debilitating nausea and she stopped throwing up in seconds, although she had it as an injection rather than a tablet. Not sure if it’s given often for self-administration.

Copper-alloy wristbands and similar talismans work only if you are highly responsive to placebo effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395522
Virgin Atlantic has fucked up pricing mostly because it had more difficulty with covid as it is a smaller airline. It declared bankruptcy because of covid (not a going out of business bankruptcy, a restructure/refinance bankruptcy) and is still not doing well. Delta almost owns half the company, operates a bunch of its flights, and Virgin Atlantic is joining Delta's alliance. Prices will probably settle down to standard variability this or next year, but smaller airlines all have more (as a percentage, not total number) weird situations such as you described than larger airlines.

I am my own boss so I can go out any time.
I’ve been doing it since I was a kid, and my dad has been doing it since the 60s. I guess it’s more of an education thing. I just want to try and see more things. When you’re abroad, at least for me, you become like a toddler. Everything is brand new and you need to learn quick to adapt, whether it’s a few words in a new languages or new cultural norms to get used to. And finally, learn about a lot of things, such as local history, geographical data, wildlife (I do birdwatching and there are species of birds you can never see in other places). Why just look at pictures in the book I have read instead of actually going there?
Learning is life’s greatest pleasure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2399138
I get a lift from being in new and unfamiliar environments. I also like landscapes/cityscapes, museums, concerts, and historical sites, but even just sitting at a coffeeshop in a place I don’t know is inherently exciting to me. I also get a weird kick out of buying completely mundane things like toothpaste and deodorant. Banal everyday life places and things that are recognizable but not the same are genuinely entertaining for me.

I also like listening to local languages and trying to pick some up, and I like to try unfamiliar food, although I’m not a “foodie” or glutton.

My brother, on the other hand, finds travel inherently uncomfortable, and would generally rather stay home. He will travel to visit me and my family, or to see friends once in a while, and he has fun, but it’s not something he would choose for fun if someone else weren’t making him do it. Different strokes.

Spend a few nights in ryokan for a Japanese feel, some have outdoor hotsprings, some have private ones.

Spend the rest in a hostel to meet people because you are alone, then go together to arcades, purikuri, kaiten sushi, curry bar, ramen bar, and izakaya. Try some specialty cafes. >>2401758
So I've travelled most of south and Central America but for what you say you're after I would strongly recommend going to the Caribbean coast of Colombia. You say you have dollars so I'm assuming you're a burger, you can get relatively cheap flights to Bogota then bus up to Cartagena, when I was there (admittedly it was years ago) it was the cheapest place pretty much in the world to do your Padi. $200 for the whole course, dives, lunches and you got to meet cool people, there's also a bunch of good hostels and overall it's a great vibe, once you're done you can also head to the national park and live cheap Robinson Crusoe style, it's very kino, pretty sure it was called tyrona and it was up the coast from Cartagena.
Belize in comparison is expensive, don't get me wrong the diving is great but you have to fly or boat out the cays and then it's mostly expensive hotels, I did cat caulker and then a few other places, can't remember the name, it was nice but not sure it's for the bang for you buck that Colombia has.
Also the blue hole if I'm remembering correctly is about 40 metres deep, when you take your first Padi which in guessing is still called the open water it only allows you on dives down to 30 metres. To get down further your need your advanced. Don't get me wrong there will be dodgy people who will take you without it but not really worth the risk imo, sure you could snorkel the surface but kinda boring.
I've not been to Bonaire but I did Honduras, pretty cool and they have awesome whale sharks but it's a bit trickier to get there and all in all unless you're just in the area it's a faff. I'd defo say do Colombia, it's awesome

I was stationed in Japan for four years in Sasebo, which is about halfway between Fukuoka and Nagasaki on the island of Kyushu. Can give you a rough rundown on my takeaways that stick out in my mind about Japan although it may not directly relate to what you're asking.
>Pros
Meme answer but I really enjoyed the food. I'm not a huge fan of seafood but I came to at least appreciate it in all its forms while here. There's a lot of good restaurants and places that one can just kind of stumble across. The best places were ones I didn't even seek out, just walked past and peeked my head in and got a table. There's a lot of cool stuff to see, especially in Nagasaki, Kagoshima, and Fukuoka. I didn't go to Tokyo or anything like that, but Osaka was fun. If you like night-life, I guess Fukuoka was alright. I have more but I can elaborate elsewhere
>Cons
I found Japanese people very boring, plain, and mundane people but extremely arrogant and annoying polite. Hard to really put it into words, but they're a very irritating people when it's not just simple transaction. Everything here has this certain feeling of dreariness and soullessness. A part of me wants to almost say that this country never really seemed to progress past the 90s, and it's stuck in like a stasis from that time. But I don't know, I wasn't around then.

For your purposes, since you seem like a tradlarper, Japanese women are incredibly boring and most of the ones you're going to meet who are going to be interested in you as a foreigner are literal trash, who just want to ape Western culture and you're part of their aesthetic as their foreign boyfriend. There are gems, I've seen it with guys I served with, but most of the non-trash women aren't going to really associate with foreigners.

I will also be solo travelling in Rome mid Feb.

Just book a hostel, although I booked mine about a month ago and it was nearly already fully booked then. So you might have some trouble getting somewhere at short notice.
Who you get in your room is pot luck, but its pretty much certain there will be at least some other solo travellers.
My last solo trip everyone in the room was solo, which I think was by design, but I'm not sure how many other hostels do that.

If you're friendly and confident and are not an ugly socially awkward freak then people will be more than willing to chat to you and probably go out for a meal and or drinks.
Just say hi to whoever's in the room when you walk in. Group travellers in your room may well also let you join up with them, its just a bit less common because sometimes they want to get on with their own thing.
Privacy wise try and get a hostel that has a curtain that goes across your bed, if you can't then it shouldnt be too much of a problem anyway, especially only for a few days.

Worth noting that its Valentines day on the 14th, I was slightly worried that the rooms would just be a bunch of couples, but I expect not because that's hardly very romantic.
On the positive side the single girls might be a lot more up for being romanced.

The problem with SEPTA is that it's not as used as other cities' transit systems, so there's a solid chance you'll end up almost completely alone at a station if you're using it past like 6-7pm and that's very bad news and depending on where you are. Actually pretty solid, acknowledging that D*blin is not a place to stay for longer than a couple of days. That being said I'd add the Croke Park Museum and swap out Temple Bar for Camden Street (better pubs and restaurants there in what's not as much of a tourist trap).

Speaking of I can't say much for Kerry. Don't bother going to Dingle to see Fungie because that fucker's dead.
Limerick's decent but definitely a day trip.
If you have the chance/time the Aran Islands might be worth trying for a view of rural island life.
Galway - you need more than a day on this and the surrounding area. Clifden is worth the trek out and the Killary Fjords (the only ones in Ireland) are a good sight. Also Kylemore Abbey. Galway city alone is a day along with the rest of these.
Potentially go up to Sligo as well it's underrated. Donegal has some nice stuff.
Every county/city/area not mentioned in your itinerary or my recommedations is not worth even looking at, especially the midlands which are some nice scenery and absolute shitholes of towns, and doubly so for most D*blin suburbs (also Louth).
Generally speaking look out for the wide array of B&Bs available in some of the locations, there's probably good stuff on offer. A hostel might be the best thing to do for Dublin if you don't want to spend at least 100 on a hotel room (which you will).
There's only certain drives that take a long time and all of them you have broken up in your itinerary so in general it should be fine to drive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Are you renting a car? How long are you in Ireland for?
You could take the train to Galway or Killarney and use either of those as a base for exploring the west coast. Killarney is more touristy but the scenery is a bit better. But Galway has better cultural stuff and I prefer it. You could go from Galway through Connemara and up through Mayo, to Donegal to see real untouched, untouristy Ireland with great scenery. Slieve League cliffs in Donegal are way higher than the overrated cliffs of Moher. There's a great deal of good hiking out in Donegal and Connemara as well as a lot of Irish speakers and traditional music.
From Killarney, I'd reccomend the Dingle Peninsula. Don't drive the Conor pass until you get comfortable driving on the other side of the road on very narrow winding mountain passes. Do the Dingle archaeology tour and visit the Blasket Islands visitor centre.
From Galway, I'd recommend visiting Connemara and especially the Aran Islands (either Inis Mor or Inis Oirr; stay overnight on one of them to get a feel of the place.).
From Dublin you can take a lot of different day trips by bus to places around the country although I don't reccomend just staying in Dublin. A good little bus trip from Dublin goes to the Glendalough ruins in the Wicklow mountains just south of Dublin, as well as the town of Kilkenny. Another one I highly recommend is the Newgrange tour by Mary Gibbons.
Dublin city itself does not need more than two or so days. Book of Kells is overrated and you just get to see one page of it after standing in line for hours. Temple Bar sucks and is expensive. The Molly Malone statue is just a statue. Visit Kilmainham Jail or the GPO to learn about Irish history. Glasnevin Cemetery is really cool as well, do the Irish history tour which takes you up the tower. There is a really good pub next to it called Gravediggers that some say pulls the best pint in Dublin.

Even around El Poblado I found plenty of unsavory characters and I honestly felt like I could be robbed at any moment.
The highlights of the trip to Medellin were the times I wasn't in Medellin itself. Guatape, Jardin, Santa Fe de Antioquia were so much better. Mind you, I'm not really a party person, so my opinion doesn't account for that kind of stuff.
Medellin does have a bunch of cool viewpoints as it's in a valley surrounded by mountains, I would recommend trying going up Cerro Pan de Azucar - easy to get to via metrocable, some 45 minutes of walking and you're on top, the walk didn't feel unsafe either and there were plenty of people chilling on top (pic related). >>2395382
Been there last year, I will summarize:

Tolls EVERYWHERE, factor that into travel costs, probably paying about 10 euro every 100 km.
Look for quieter spots that dont have tons of "foreign" tourists, my personal favourite was Kamena Vourla - it was mostly greeks on domestic holidays. Second favourite was Mytikas because it was much quieter than others.
Many of the roads and streets are poor and the drivers are crazy so always keep it in the back of your head to be careful.
Snacks are expensive, you want a bottle of coke? Some places sell 500ml cokes for 3 euro.
There are quite varying temperatures across the country, next to the ocean is generally cooler but in the midlands it can be agonizingly hot.
If driving, make sure to visit petrol stations often, lots of them close on a Sunday too so don't get stuck!
The Greeks are very kind (when they are not driving) and will talk to you if they can, some even took us home and were very hospitable.
Pay attention to google maps - if you are sure you have the right place but the journey says it takes a crazy long time, there is likely a valid reason (landslides etc).
A lot of places do not let you put normal toilet roll in the toilet - I wish I was kidding but they expect you to shit, wipe, and put your shitty wipes in the bin next to the toilet. This was honestly the most disgusting thing about Greece, I didn't even see one bidet.

>>2395382
• Greek food is the best, focus on grilled meat, fish
• Try desserts: galatopita, bougatsa, galaktoboureko
• Greek fast food is patrician. It's hard for foreign fast food companies to get a foothold because local fast food is so good. The go-to is Gyro or meaet skewers(kalamaki).
• They got some bomb ass sour cherry drinks and sodas. Try the sour cherry one from Loux, amazing.
• Try feta from a barrel. The Olympos one from a grocery store is good.
• In Athens there are a lot of amazing eateries at all price ranges.
• Avoid tourist traps and people who holler at you to sit in their place.
• Unlike spain that barely has 30-50% (depending on area) of households with air conditioning, Greece has 99%. Who's the third country now?
• Greece is a bit far behind technologically and many roads are completely shit. It's not great for shopping either. Around Athens' Kolonaki there are some shops though like Balenciaga and high-end watches boutiques. You won't find Uniqlo though.
• Greeks are super nice
• Some Greeks have inferiority complex and are whiny bitches. The lowest class ones are nearer middle-eastern in their behavior instead of more north/western. Kefalonia and islands around the Ionian sea are colored by Italian heritage and genetics. They were never controlled by the Ottomans either. Completely different from the Cyrpean mutts or people from south Aegean islands.

cont.
• There is a lot of hidden wealth in Greece that is related to maritime shipping. Unbeknownst to many that aren't familiar with the sector, Greece boasts the largest fleet in terms of capacity, mogging even China and Japan.

People there are a bit tougher and there's a Vendetta culture going on reminiscent of Italy. Often you'll see signage that has holes in it because of a shoot-out. They might be a bit taller and have blue eyes. Different phenotype.
• Athens is basically many generations of different socio-economic backgrounds stacked on top of each other so there are stark differences of income. Someone who works in the shipping industry and does well might make north of 200k USD while an average person might struggle to get by with 800USD a month working at a grocery store clerk and never getting enough money to move out of the family home.
• Distances in Athens can be quite large and the center is living hell during summer because of all the concrete that makes it like an over. During June-August, try to avoid Athens or keep it short or do activities after the sun sets.
• Transport is not that good in Athens, just use Uber.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395382
The islands are all nice, but many are a bit dull. There really isn't a whole lot to do on them and once youve seen one or two you've seen all. If you like quieter islands with hiking I could highly recommend Amorgos. Santorini is pretty incredible and worth visiting. If you want a party island then Ios or Mykonos are your best options.

The comment about staying on the mainland but staying coastal is a good one. In the Peloponnese you have places like Nafplio which are beautiful and highly worth a couple of nights. Sparta was interesting but one night was enough (mystras near by well worth 1/2 day).

Olympia is ok for the main site, but a tourist trap overall. Delphi was interesting too. But touristy but interesting for sure. There is a little town below Delphi called Galaxidi that is great for lunch.

Athens is really the highlight. You can stay cheaply in the center area and be within walking distance of all the best stuff.

My recommended itinerary for 2 weeks would be something like:

> Athens 1 night
> Get ferry boat down to a couple of islands (2 nights on each)
> Ferry back to Athens (2 nights to explore Athens)
> Hire car and drive around Peloponnese visiting Nafplio (2 nights), Sparta/Mystras (1 night)
> Olympia (1 night)
> Delphi (1-2 nights)
Athens (1 night) -> home.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2397919
Food sucked, idk where people are getting the idea that Greek food is good. It’s okay at best. Even at “high end” traditional Greek places I didn’t find it all too good. Seafood is okay.
Most of the cool stuff in Athens can be seen in a couple days, a week at most. I walked around most of the city and there really isn’t much to see besides the acropolis and the surrounding archeological sights, the acropolis museum, etc. The nightlife is pretty mediocre by all standards, most neighborhoods are quite rundown and don’t look anything like the islands. If I could do it again, I’d go in the summer and only stay in Athens for maybe 3 or 4 days, then spend the rest of the time touring the islands. Greece is just kinda meh in the off seasons, I posted about it here before but I just felt like an inconvenience, i met a handful of friendly people but nowhere near what I experienced in other European countries. It really wasn’t too different from turkey in terms of standoffish-ness, and frankly the service in turkey was way better. I had this rosie idea of what Athens would be like based on all the historical sites I had read about looked like, but most of those are renderings, and the mainland looks nothing like the pictures of islands in OPs picrelated.
TLDR Athens for a few days max then hit the islands, preferably during summer season otherwise it will be very dead and boring

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2404447
>repeat ad infinitum
“Ad infinitum” hasn’t been possible for a long time now.

I’m old enough to remember a time when people stayed for literal years on one-month exemptions secured at overland border runs (before the overland exemption was reduced to fifteen days and the arrival by air exemption increased to 45 for most nationalities), but the authorities have always hated it, and the law was slightly vague. It was commonly understood that you wouldn’t be allowed to stay for more than 180 days per year on any combination of tourist visas and exemptions, but this was actually just a guideline without specific legal terms to back it up, and enforcement was sporadic and unpredictable.

The most recent edition of the Thai Royal Gazette actually now specifies that visitors are entitled to two consecutive visa or exemption renewals per year (there’s local press coverage of this you can look up, or you can read the TRG if you enjoy badly translated legalese). It remains irregular in practice—it’s still possible to get in a third time in a row, but it’s entirely at the discretion of whatever border agent looks at your passport, or if you’re going the tourist-visa route, at the discretion of your consular official at the neighboring embassy. But word from friends in Thailand is that since the corona emergency measures were lifted, they’ve been consistently warning people coming in for third exemptions that this is their last time.

It’s possible to get refused at any time if the authorities think you’re doing things you’re not supposed to be doing with a tourist visa or exemption, such as living in Thailand long-term. They’re still offering five-year “Elite” visas, and they’ve just rolled out a new ten-year visa that includes provisions that can apply to some remote workers—they want you to get one of these or one of the extant non-immigrant visa categories if you intend to hang around for a long time.

The Czech attitude towards pretty much anything is "I don't give a shit just don't bother me". That goes for weed, it's not technically legal there but there are tons of head shops and references to weed around Prague. I haven't tried getting any over there but I'm guessing you could ask in one of the head shops, or try your luck on a dating app. Otherwise bars like the ones already mentioned are a good bet. Whenever I've smoked weed in other European countries it's been from the Czech Republic and it was good stuff.

Brno is a cool city, not nearly as touristy as Prague. I stayed there for a few nights and went to Moravsky Krumlov to see Alfons Mucha's masterpiece on display in a 900 year old castle. Also the ossuaries are pretty wild.

Cesky Krumlov is beautiful, definitely recommend spending a couple nights there if you like old castles. Also Hluboka nad Vltavou is one of the most beautiful castles in the country and it's not far.

Pilsen is cool but definitely more of a "locals-only" vibe except in the touristy spots like the Pilsner Urquell brewery. The beer and food is pretty exceptional.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391105
If you're used to USA or UK prices then the entirety of the Czech Republic will feel very affordable to you, unless you're trying to stay in high end AirBnbs/hotels and only eat at tourist trap restaurants. For $50 to $100 USD/night you should be able to find very comfortable places to stay in good locations, and I'm sure you can find cheaper stays than that if you really dig.

I think every single restaurant meal I ate in the Czech Republic was less than $15 USD, and that would probably get you an appetizer + entrée + at least one large beer. Otherwise, I would go to a grocery store in the morning and get some bread for like $1.50, some cheese for $2, some meat for $2 and some apples for $2 and be set for the day. Bus, train and tram tickets are extremely affordable, I don't think I've ever paid more than $10 and that was for a longer train ride.

In restaurants make sure you understand how tipping works - for example, after you ask to pay, the waiter will bring the card machine to your table, tell you that the price is 250 Kc, and then you have to say "please make it 300" or whatever you want. I think 10-15% is adequate for a tip there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ignore the people telling you to avoid Prague. It's fucking amazing. It's better with all the expats and foreigners. It's much easier to make friends. Everyone is excited to be there. It's crazy cheap. $1.50 beers, 500/month apartments, gorgeous architecture, cheap food, great public transport, low crime. What's not to like?

I really like Czesky Krumlov too. We spent 3 days there and I made friends on the first night with a bunch of locals at a bar. The food was really good and there were a couple great bars in town. We rafted the river and stopped at breweries along the way. This little food joint in town called Krčma Šatlava served the best meal Ive ever eaten in Europe. It was a giant meat plate cooked over a wood fire with like 6 different BBQ meats. We ate there twice.
